A black 1986 Ford LTD expertly maneuvers around the INS vehicles, executing a dramatic sideways stop before their headlights.

Two men emerge from the LTD, wearing identical black suits, white shirts, and dark ties. The older of the pair, Dee, appears simply exhausted, while his fiftyish partner Kay epitomizes world-weariness. They stride past the agents toward the lined-up immigrants, with Kay greeting each one warmly in Spanish.

An eerie silence falls over the road before the mysterious agents escort their chosen subject across the road and over a small rise, leaving bewildered INS agents behind. Kay produces a laser device, swiftly splitting the man's clothing to reveal his true form - a 4.5-foot-tall alien creature with scaly skin, tentacles like a snail, and eyestalks that move independently.

The creature, supported by a stick like a puppet, responds to questioning with an incomprehensible mixture of grunts and squeaks. Suddenly, a horrified gasp breaks the tension. Kay, Dee, and one of the alien's swiveling eyestalks turn to find Agent Janus standing there, paralyzed with fear. As Dee struggles with his dropped weapon, other INS agents appear over the rise, shouting questions. With approaching vehicles' headlights beginning to illuminate the scene, Kay reaches for a mysterious metallic device from his pocket.
564:
In a tense moment, Kay attempts to light a cigarette, striking a match only to have it mysteriously extinguish before reaching its target. His sharp glance upward reveals a horrifying sight - Tony, the counter attendant, plastered to the ceiling corner by viscous, dripping fluid, his lifeless body still clutching a can of Raid, face frozen in terror.

Laurel's desperation becomes evident as Jay's expression shifts from confident to shocked, his hand instinctively moving toward his weapon. The scene erupts into chaos when Kay bursts into the morgue just as Edgar reveals himself, violently throwing aside the examination table. In an instant, weapons are drawn - Jay with his Noisy Cricket, Kay wielding his series four deatomizer, while Edgar uses Laurel as a human shield, pressing a shotgun beneath her chin.

Edgar retreats deeper into the morgue toward a window overlooking an air shaft. As Jay and Kay cautiously advance, Edgar makes his move, crashing through the glass and launching himself and Laurel upward over a railing. The agents follow but find themselves staring up a smooth-walled shaft, impossible to climb.

Jay races into the street, frantically checking numerous taxis at an intersection, alarming passengers as he goes. Meanwhile, at MIB headquarters, agents rush in beneath the World's Fair mural amid frenzied activity. A piercing alarm sounds as the main viewing screen displays an ominous green line extending from the Arquillian ship to Earth, triggering every warning system in the facility.

Kay and Zed's attention snaps upward, their scowls deepening as they study the massive World's Fair mural that has been present throughout - specifically its two distinctive towers crowned with flying saucers from humanity's first alien encounter. The scene shifts to the actual Flushing Meadows fairgrounds, where these same towers stand in reality, as a taxi screeches to a halt roughly a hundred yards from the perimeter fence.
569:
At MiB headquarters, the elevator doors slide open as a Worm Alien gestures toward the counter in its native language. Edwards, transfixed by the sight, needs Kay to pull him along. They enter a room filled with sophisticated equipment stacked everywhere, where Edwards can't resist picking up a small yellow ball before they exit.

Moving across the main floor, they approach a massive screen displaying a world map dotted with thousands of blinking lights and scrolling data. Live feeds of aliens appear on the monitors, including bony fingers and a stern-faced alien wearing cat-eye glasses, which 4-Eyes uploads as Edwards watches in amazement.

Zed approaches, evaluating Edwards with scrutiny before speaking. Edwards discovers a pristine black suit and gleaming shoes waiting in a white locker. Meanwhile, Kay accesses a terminal displaying Edwards's complete identity: birth certificate, driver's license, social security card, and library card.

In a cramped white booth, Edwards endures the painful process of having his fingerprints altered, pressing his hands against a ten-fingered keypad that glows red and emits a searing sound. Kay methodically erases Edwards's identity documents as the computer screen shows his full name - JAMES DARREL EDWARDS III. The cursor moves left to right, gradually eliminating letters from his name.

The transformation culminates with Edwards - now Jay - emerging from the locker room looking impeccable in his perfectly fitted suit, tie properly positioned. He completes the ensemble by donning the signature sunglasses.

Meanwhile, Rosenberg, an elderly man, exits his distinctive shop carrying a cat and an ornate rosewood jewelry box. He meticulously places the cat atop the box while securing the shop's five locks. After finishing, he awkwardly waddles away with both cat and box tucked under his arms. Across the street, Edgar observes from his Orkin van, a piece of graying, crusty skin hanging from his neck as he watches the older man leave the jewelry shop on Thirty-Fifth Street.
57:
Breathing deeply, Evelyn raises her head to look at him, meeting his genuinely puzzled expression. Gittes sighs as she begins to cry softly. He looks over at her, but her hair obscures most of her face. A heavy silence falls between them, broken only when she nods. He exits the car forcefully, slamming the door behind him.

Water sprays directly onto Gittes' head in the shower. Exhausted, he clings to the nozzle as water cascades down. After shutting off the shower, he weakly reaches for a towel, carefully dabbing his injured nose. Now dressed in elegant silk pajamas, he walks to the window where morning light streams in. After drawing the curtains, he collapses onto the bed, lying motionless atop the covers.

The phone rings. Gittes lets it continue briefly before answering silently. Rising slowly to one elbow, he listens, then hangs up and falls back. When it rings again, he curses and answers, but the caller disconnects before he can speak.

At a bungalow courtyard with its sickly green stucco and narrow walkway, Gittes approaches the slightly open front door. After knocking, he enters to find morning light filtering through half-open blinds, dust particles dancing in the light beams. The stillness is palpable.

Down the hall, under a telephone table, something catches his eye. As he approaches, what initially appears grotesque reveals itself to be merely a wilted lettuce head. The kitchen entrance is littered with scattered radishes and onions. Inside, he discovers Ida Sessions lying on her back, surrounded by spilled groceries. Melted ice cream pools around her body, and ants stream across it into her open mouth. He recognizes her as the woman who had impersonated Evelyn Mulwray.

Carefully examining her handbag's contents on the counter, he finds a wallet containing some bills, her driver's license, and a Screen Actors Guild card. After noting these items, he replaces them precisely. He methodically checks the broom closet, pantry, and nearly empty Frigidaire before stepping over her body to investigate a partially open door across the hall.

Upon entering and switching on the light, Gittes discovers Escobar and a plainclothed man standing by the bathroom's bedroom entrance. As he turns around, he notices a third man approaching from the bedroom. The Assistant moves toward Gittes, who prepares for confrontation.
570:
Inside MIB headquarters, Zed presides over operations from his circular, windowed office elevated above the main floor. Jay and Kay sit across from him while he shuffles through paperwork, five video screens behind his desk displaying other Men in Black stationed globally, each monitor showing different city names and ticking clocks. When his computer suddenly beeps, Zed turns to check it. After their meeting, Jay and Kay exit the building's front entrance.

Meanwhile, Rosenberg, clutching an ornate box and his beloved cat, exits a cab in the meat-packing district. An Orkin van quietly pulls up across the street moments later. Rosenberg enters Leshko's, a Russian diner, where his eyes adjust to the dim lighting. He spots an imposing yet peculiar-looking man in his fifties dining alone. Approaching cautiously, Rosenberg places the ornate box on the table. After a tense moment of silent observation, the two men share a formal, mafia-like embrace, both visibly moved. They finally separate and sit, conversing in an unusual alien language with subtitles.

In another scene, Edgar slowly follows someone in his truck. The Driver exchanges documents, with the other party providing two additional cards. Mrs. Redgick, heavily pregnant and moaning in pain, sits in the front seat. Kay suddenly straightens up as she screams again, and Redgick exits the vehicle concerned. Without warning, a tentacle whips out from between Mrs. Redgick's legs, cracking once before wrapping around the doorpost. A second tentacle emerges, constricting around Jay's neck. Jay looks down to find the creature cooing and nuzzling against his chest before it vomits on him. Later, back in the car, Jay cleans the last traces of vomit from his suit while Kay starts the engine.

The scene shifts to Kay frantically flipping through supermarket tabloids while Jay stands behind him, appearing uncomfortable. Kay selects a copy of the Weekly World News, pays a dollar, and dramatically slams it on the hood, opened to a headline so enormous it seems more suited for announcing the apocalypse.
577:
A kaleidoscope of emotions flashes across her face - shock, embarrassment, pleasure, and conflict all intermingling. Joe, delightfully bewildered by these interactions, studies Susan without answering her question, while Drew notices their apparent intimacy. Following Parrish to the door, Joe initially stops, then pivots to follow him through the correct exit as Parrish returns to the bedroom.

After testing the bed springs, Joe encounters Coyle, who appears sheepish about his peanut butter. Joe raises his spoonful in a playful toast to the staff before wandering into a magnificent indoor Olympic pool area, with windows showcasing the city's skyline.

Susan swims professional-looking laps in her black Speedo while Joe, still savoring his peanut butter, observes her unnoticed. Only when her barrel turn reveals his shadow does she spot him and climb halfway up the ladder, gesturing toward some towels. Joe, juggling his peanut butter-laden spoon between hands, eventually places it in his mouth to properly handle the large Turkish towel for Susan.

As he finishes his peanut butter, methodically cleaning his gums, Susan watches, fascinated. Uncertain what to do with the spoon, he awkwardly shifts it between hands until Susan extends hers, taking it to place on the towel table.

The scene shifts to Parrish observing Joe's disheveled tie - now a wayward strip of silk across his collarbone. Startled by something, Parrish scrutinizes Joe before approaching to fix his tie. With some effort, he completes the knot and positions it perfectly, then turns Joe toward a mirror. Joe, clearly pleased with his reflection, rises onto his tiptoes.

They move through the crowd together, Joe appearing perfectly at ease while Parrish seems uncharacteristically uncomfortable, struggling with unspoken thoughts until he suddenly speaks out. As Jennifer hurries back to the office, Parrish reaches the Board Room door, hesitates momentarily while acknowledging something, then enters with Joe close behind.
580:
In a moment of shock, Parrish stands silent before ascending the stairs. Joe maintains a guarded position below, watching as Parrish makes his way down. When Parrish speaks, Joe remains quiet, sensing his tone. Parrish carefully evaluates Joe before setting his jaw firmly.

Susan appears distracted as Parrish stares down at his cards, her tone revealing that his words haven't registered. Meanwhile, Quince experiments with the wines, mixing red and white in one glass with an embarrassed smile before draining it. After Joe observes him, Quince finishes another glass and departs, leaving Parrish and Joe in silence.

Joe contemplates deeply as Parrish's words begin to affect him. Later, Joe leaves Parrish's study with heavy steps, lost in thought until the party's bright lights, laughter, and music jolt him back to reality. Momentarily confused, he encounters someone waiting. They share a passionate kiss and deep embrace, but Joe struggles to respond afterward, falling into silence.

Susan becomes emotionally overwhelmed, steadied by Joe before he leaves her with a wan smile. Meanwhile, Parrish sits alone by the window, detached from the muted celebrations outside. Joe enters the room, met by Parrish's sympathetic gaze and patient silence until Quince, flushed with excitement, interrupts with a knock.

After considering the news, Parrish activates the speakerphone as Quince departs. Through the party's atmosphere, Quince leads Drew, who makes a grand entrance, greeting guests while Quince appreciates the irony. In Parrish's office, with Joe lurking in a corner, Drew enters and takes a seat as Quince excuses himself.

Joe loses his composure, leaving Parrish speechless. Despite Parrish's subtle, pleading headshake, Joe responds with confident nods. Drew pays full attention as Joe steps forward and Parrish turns off the speakerphone. Drew stares at Joe in disbelief.

The scene shifts back to the party, where Parrish hesitantly waves and steps away to growing applause and cheers as dance music resumes. Quince enthusiastically congratulates him. Parrish finds Allison and they share a tight embrace before being separated by the crowd. Finally, he sees Susan, whose smile carries a hint of melancholy.
583:
In the aircraft cabin, flight attendant Trina surveys the passengers from her jump seat with a warm smile. Whip, in the cockpit, takes possession of the phone before secretly pouring vodka from a miniature bottle into a juice container, concealed from passenger view. After discarding three small bottles, he takes a long drink just as Margaret exits the bathroom, which he then enters.

Meanwhile, Nicole arrives at a dilapidated apartment complex, rushing up to the second floor. Finding her door slightly ajar, she enters with key in hand. After exchanging smiles with someone in the doorway, she kicks the door shut and carelessly throws her bag, knocking over a box. Among the scattered contents, she notices a syringe. The apartment contains framed photos showing a younger, happier Nicole with her mother.

With practiced precision, Nicole prepares the syringe, tapping it lightly and expelling a small droplet. She secures a tourniquet with her teeth, injects herself, and gradually succumbs to the drug's effects. Her body relaxes, the tourniquet slips from her mouth, and her head drops to one side as her pupils contract to pinpoints. She clutches a cocaine packet from Kip before collapsing. The packet falls just beyond her reach, and as her hand makes a final futile attempt to grasp it, footsteps appear beneath the door.

Back on the plane, Whip dozes in the cockpit, paper covering his eyes beneath sunglasses. Suddenly, Ken's yoke jerks violently, slipping from his grip as Whip struggles for control of the diving aircraft. The landing gear deploys, with one wheel malfunctioning during retraction. Margaret, in the galley, grabs the phone and unbuckles herself while panicked passengers clutch the seats ahead of them. Cammie falls, striking her head and lying motionless.

As Whip banks left, the aircraft inverts completely. The side-stick moves forward as Cammie's unconscious form rests against the cabin ceiling. Trina spots a young boy slipping from his seat and crawls to secure him. Outside Georgian Gardens, Nicole is being wheeled alongside Fran when the inverted plane passes overhead. Warning lights flash in the cockpit as the plane rights itself, sending Cammie tumbling onto passengers and Trina crashing against the bulkhead. The left engine erupts in fire and smoke.
585:
After being helped from his hospital bed by a nurse, exposing his buttocks in the process, Whip receives a visitor with a video camera. Once the nurse departs, Harling places his hand on Whip's head before leaving himself. Whip drifts off, only to be startled awake later in the darkness. After clicking on the light and cautiously checking the corridor, he spots a nurse at the reception desk and carefully makes his way down the hall with his cane.

On the stairs, he discovers Nicole smoking a cigarette. Though she initially moves to leave, she decides to stay, and Whip positions himself against the wall facing her, lighting his own cigarette. Their moment is interrupted by a gaunt patient with an IV pole climbing the stairs. Nicole tosses her pack, and the patient, cigarette dangling from his mouth, takes his IV pole down the stairs. Before departing herself, Nicole wipes away a tear and offers Whip a smile before ascending the stairs.

Outside, a black Cadillac exits the hospital parking structure, passing gathered news crews. Harling opens a beer, takes a drink, and hands Whip a package containing cash. Later, a car turns onto a dirt road, passing a weathered shed before arriving at an old farmhouse. After parking, Whip retrieves a hidden key from above a veranda post and brings his bag inside.

The house reveals a well-furnished living room with a retro stereo and framed photos. Still wearing a bandage over his eyes, Whip surveys his surroundings before taking his plastic bag to the kitchen table. After plugging in his iPhone charger, he discovers 127 voice messages waiting for him.

Standing at a bureau, Whip contemplates his prescription pills while eyeing a whiskey decanter and another liquor bottle near the stereo. After a moment of internal struggle, evident in his lip-licking and jaw-clenching, he makes a decisive choice. Using his cane for support, he systematically purges the house of all substances: flushing pills down the toilet, emptying liquor bottles in the sink, disposing of beer cans and bottles from the fridge, and flushing marijuana from a wooden box. With unwavering determination, he methodically searches every cabinet, removing and discarding all remaining bottles and cans.
588:
In his dark suit, Whip observes a passing procession until a young boy's touch on his arm draws his attention. Turning around, he discovers Margaret, and they embrace warmly. Margaret gathers her son close, and together they watch Trevor depart to find his father. After sharing another emotional hug, Margaret gazes at Whip with tearful eyes. They remain frozen, looking at each other, until Whip tenderly wipes away her tears with his thumb. Margaret's expression softens with sympathy, her brow furrowed, before Whip kisses her goodbye and departs.

Later, in a parking lot, Whip leans against his car, watching an airplane soar overhead when Nicole approaches briskly. They embrace, and she presents him with a Zippo lighter. He places a cigarette between his lips. Inside, as a man stands at a podium, Whip sits slouched in his chair. Most attendees raise their hands, Nicole among them, while Whip crosses his arms before leaving.

Whip drives to a bar, entering as his co-pilot Ken appears on the news, only to exit shortly after. At the hospital, he peers into a private room before tapping his cane on the doorframe. Inside, a nurse tends to Ken's wounds, his left leg supported by a brace. Vicky and Ken acknowledge Whip's presence, and Ken addresses the nurse. After closing the door, Whip sits down, eventually rising to leave. Ken reaches for Whip's hands, and after a moment of hesitation, Whip accepts the gesture.

At Whip's family farm, Nicole notices the hangar lights illuminated. Inside, Whip, still wearing his tie with rolled-up sleeves, works on a Cessna. He descends from a ladder to greet Nicole with a kiss before taking a sip of beer. Nicole spots cocaine on the table.

Later, Nicole sits on the bed, finishing a phone call while packing her belongings, ignoring Whip. After taking a large drink and setting down the bottle, Whip enters the bedroom. Nicole walks past him, touching her head before sitting on the bed. He joins her, and their foreheads meet tenderly. They share a kiss as he pulls her into an embrace.

The next morning, Whip lies fully clothed and asleep on the bed. Nicole stands at the bedroom doorway, watching him before placing an envelope marked with his name between his lighter and a whiskey bottle. Carrying her suitcase and basket, she walks away from the house to Sheila's van, hidden behind trees. As the van drives away, Whip discovers the envelope and hurries to read it.
595:
Armed with a small tin and scissors, a man attempts to cut a peculiar plant with waving vine-like tentacles. Harry, walking by, notices him and approaches, startling Slughorn who nervously glances around before retreating. As Harry ascends a grassy hillock, Slughorn follows at a distance until they come upon Hagrid, his dog, and an enormous dead spider. After Harry's gestured demonstration, a piece of the spider breaks off, which Slughorn drops to the ground. Looking up at the towering Hagrid, Slughorn bows his head solemnly.

Inside Hagrid's cottage, Harry watches as the increasingly intoxicated pair interact. Hagrid eventually succumbs to drowsiness, his head falling back against his high-backed chair. Harry's initial grin fades as Slughorn fixes him with a meaningful look. Harry gulps nervously, his scarred forehead visible as he stands. Slughorn gazes at him with widening, moistening eyes.

In a pivotal moment, Slughorn extracts a memory using his wand, pressing it to his temple and drawing out a silvery wisp. With trembling hands, he holds up a test tube, and Harry steadies him as the memory drops into the container. Later, in his study, Dumbledore pours this crucial memory into the pensieve.

The memory reveals young Tom Riddle, turning from Slughorn toward a fire, hands clasped behind his back, fiddling with a ring before facing Slughorn with cold eyes. After the memory ends, Dumbledore silences Harry with a raised hand and walks troubled to sit on nearby steps. He hurriedly retrieves something from his desk - a ring that Harry touches, setting it spinning. Images flash by: teenage Tom, the orphanage boy, pebbles on a windowsill, a coastal postcard, and Voldemort, until the ring stops its rotation. Harry flexes his neck as Dumbledore scrutinizes him while he catches his breath.

The scene shifts to the astronomy tower, where Snape abruptly departs, briefly pausing as he encounters Harry on the stairs. Harry continues upward, self-consciously rubbing his chin. At the balustrade, after some hesitation and a nod, Harry grips Dumbledore's arm, and they launch themselves from the tower. Their journey concludes atop a sea-surrounded pinnacle, with white-capped waves crashing below.
604:
In the snowy grounds of Hogwarts, a horrific scene unfolds as Hermione, Harry, and Ron witness Katie Bell's supernatural ordeal. Katie, lying in the snow, begins convulsing violently before being wrenched upward into the air, her arms spread wide in a silent scream. When she crashes back down, her head thrashes against the ground until Hagrid arrives and gently lifts her massive frame.

Harry discovers an ornate necklace of blue stones spilled from its box in the snow. After carefully rewrapping it, they bring it inside where Professor McGonagall examines it while questioning Leanne, with Harry, Ron, and Hermione present. The tension heightens when Snape enters, magically levitating the necklace. All eyes fix upon him, with Harry being the last to break his resistant stare.

Later that night, Harry studies the Marauder's Map from his bed while Ron lies nearby, both appearing troubled. As Harry removes his glasses and places them atop the map, he notices Malfoy's presence suddenly vanishing from the parchment.

At Professor Slughorn's dinner party, the mood is light as guests enjoy their dessert until Ginny enters, visibly upset. Harry, alone among the guests, stands courteously as she approaches, discretely retrieving his dropped napkin. Meanwhile, Hermione endures Cormac's suggestive advances, turning away in discomfort when he provocatively sucks his finger. Slughorn appears startled when Harry examines some photographs, though Harry responds with a subtle smile.

Time passes, marked by an elegant hourglass adorned with green glass snakes and golden heads. The scene shifts to the Great Hall, where a dejected Ron, dressed in full Quidditch attire, confronts his precisely arranged breakfast. Hermione watches knowingly as Lavender makes a brief appearance. Harry discreetly slips a vial into his pocket before offering Ron a goblet. After drinking, Ron's mood transforms dramatically, leading to a warm handclasp with Harry while Hermione looks on disapprovingly.

The narrative culminates in a snowy Quidditch match, where a Slytherin Chaser catches the leather Quaffle, flanked by teammates as they storm toward the goal, their green capes billowing in the winter wind.
610:
The sound of gunfire echoes over a nearby street as a taxi pulls up to a graffiti-covered shopping district. A man named Sydney, luggage in hand, emerges from the cab and gazes up at a dilapidated tenement building, his eyes dropping to notice the grimy Kebab Palace below.

Mrs. Kowalski escorts Sydney to his shabby studio apartment, where she promptly slaps him before departing with an air of disdain. Later, at a nightclub, Sydney attempts to impress uninterested women with his awkward dancing, strutting between groups as the dance floor illuminates beneath him. His exaggerated hip movements and wild leaping only cause the women to retreat, leaving him deflated.

Outside, Sydney spots a leggy blonde in green entering a red-paneled bar and quickly follows her inside. Adjusting his jacket, he confidently approaches her at the bar, affecting his most suave smile. After gagging on his drink, he notices another attractive woman with flaxen hair but turns away from her. When the blonde departs, Sydney produces a newspaper clipping but accidentally spills the second woman's drink, soaking her notebook. She glares at him, brow furrowed, before gathering her belongings and leaving.

Bobbie, a curvaceous brunette wearing a zebra-print dress, takes the vacant seat. The scene shifts to Sydney's bare apartment, where Bobbie stumbles bedroom-ward. Sydney handles some records, first throwing one overhead before replacing it and wildly playing air guitar until the music abruptly stops. He turns to find Bobbie naked, leading to another slap from Mrs. Kowalski as both their eyebrows rise in surprise.

The next morning at 7:00 AM, Sydney's alarm jolts him awake. Grimacing, he fumbles to silence it as sunlight streams through his window. His attempt to adjust the venetian blinds ends in chaos as they crash down on him, causing him to tumble from bed. In the bathroom, he spits in the sink and tries to drink some yellowish water, which he promptly spits onto the mirror.

Wearing a gray t-shirt and boxers, Sydney raises a blind in the living room, revealing Bobbie half-asleep under a blanket, adjusting himself. Later, Sydney wanders through Times Square, where garish billboards compete with soaring glass-walled office towers reaching into the sky.
611:
Sidney enters the reception area, immediately colliding with an unyielding turnstile before stumbling around. In the elevator, he finds himself dwarfed by several attractive women. A petite brunette wearing a gray suit escorts him to a spacious office, where Clayton Harding, a man in a suit with distinctive shoulder-length silver hair, stands contemplatively at the window overlooking the city.

When Clayton turns to face him, Sidney reaches into his shoulder bag and presents a red t-shirt, which Clayton promptly tosses out the open window. The shirt appears to feature a post-modern review depicting Clayton as a nude king. Sidney's hopeful smile vanishes when met with Clayton's cold, indifferent stare as Clayton leafs through the offensive issue.

A formally dressed Lawrence guides Sidney to a private office, where Sidney, conscious of his bright red t-shirt, fidgets before gesturing toward a wall photograph. He recognizes the subject as the woman whose drink he'd previously spilled at the bar.

In the open-plan office, Sidney approaches Alison's desk, where she's working at her computer, and perches on its edge. A colleague in a polka dot dress nearby frowns at this. Phone pressed to his ear, Sidney examines a sheet of photographic negatives, adjusting his glasses. When the call ends, his expression falls. Peering through a magnifying glass at the contact sheet, he observes two portly middle-aged men holding wine glasses. After hitting redial and studying the receiver with a frown, he heads out.

Later, Sidney enters the lobby through a revolving door while eating a hamburger. A blonde woman in an A-line dress joins him, attempting to hold the door for an approaching colleague but quickly withdrawing her hand as it slams shut. She shoots Sidney a disapproving look as the elevator begins its descent.

When the doors open, she storms out toward Alison, who's wearing a sharp suit. Pointedly ignoring Sidney, she buries herself in a book, tight-lipped. The tension increases when an elegantly dressed woman in her mid-40s, wearing expensive sunglasses, enters and turns her back to them. Sidney's attempt to swallow his burger results in disaster - he gags, sending a chunk of partially chewed food flying onto the back of the woman's cream jacket. When he moves to clean it off, Alison grabs his wrist, shaking her head in disbelief. They hastily exit the elevator, and Sidney takes another bite of his burger while rolling his eyes at an overheard conversation.

The evening finds Sidney gazing through the window of a sleek black car cruising through Manhattan. While Alison and Lawrence remain absorbed in their mobile phones, Sidney observes the bright lights of Times Square. When he turns to his colleagues, they briefly look up from their phones before returning their attention to their screens.
613:
After awkwardly stepping over Elizabeth, Sidney receives Alison's approval to proceed. During a tense staff meeting, he disrupts the atmosphere by prodding Alison's arm, prompting Clayton to exit his position at the table's head. When Alison signals Sidney to stop, Clayton retreats to his office, trying to enjoy his sushi and edamame while Sidney persistently taps his notebook nearby. Bill's expression grows increasingly stern, his eyes narrowing with disapproval.

Later, during a confrontation between Clayton and a remorseful Sidney, the latter's hopeful demeanor fades as Clayton fixes him with a stern stare. Following Sidney's gesture toward the door, Clayton dismisses him with a nod. Sidney finds Alison supervising models selecting outfits and dramatically slumps beside her, earning only a scoff before she departs haughtily.

After exchanging waves with Lawrence, Sidney's peculiar behavior escalates when he's discovered with his nose taped like a pig's snout. Upon seeing Eleanor and Sophie approach, he frantically tears off the tape and ducks under his desk, emerging with tape still clinging to his ear. Following orders, he shuffles away to fill a container at the water cooler, where he observes Sophie holding Cuba with obvious distaste. His reaction prompts Eleanor to storm off indignantly, followed by Lawrence and Sophie.

Sidney then executes a scheme involving Cuba, cautiously checking an office before tossing a red ball through a window and quickly shutting it after the pet gives chase. His satisfaction turns to horror upon noticing a heavy stone ornament. Panicked, he bites his fist and heads for the elevator.

A struggle ensues, punctuated by a white paw's appearance. While Sophie, Eleanor, and Lawrence gather in reception, Sidney flees, with Alison pursuing only to find him leaning out a window. The search party departs, leaving Sidney relieved against the wall - until Cuba appears in a leather handbag, rising on the window cleaner's platform behind him.

The scene concludes in Clayton's office, where Sidney stands in the doorway, sipping whiskey. After tossing blue shirts onto a desk and examining them disapprovingly, he makes a gesture. Clayton approaches with a smile, and Sidney exits, only to briefly return.
615:
At a lively gathering, a bearded man with long gray hair appears unimpressed as Sydney waves to some daughters in attendance. Lost in thought, Sydney notices a beer bottle appearing over the bandstand's railing. Increasingly intoxicated, he climbs onto the railing behind the band, spreading his arms to address the crowd before they return to their conversations.

In the dim evening light, Sydney limps toward Alison, who sits alone on a swing, cradling a wine bottle and gently rocking. After an animated exchange where he runs away only to return gesturing wildly, Alison tearfully walks off, leaving Sydney stunned. Though she quickly returns, she kicks something in frustration. Sydney collapses onto the rope swing before tumbling onto the grass.

By the swimming pool, where lights dance on the rippling water, Sydney lies prone at the edge. Sophie's reflection materializes like a mirage, prompting him to roll over. She joins him, first kneeling, then lying beside him on her stomach before rolling onto her back and moving closer. As she gazes at the stars, Sydney bites his lip nervously. They exchange glances - she smiling, he transfixed - while the shifting light plays across her face as she returns her gaze skyward.

Sydney suddenly bolts through the party, meeting a man who hands him a small Ziploc bag containing white powder before rushing off again. He finds Alison struggling drunkenly with her car door. While holding her steady, his gaze drifts to Sophie by the pool. He drives Alison home along a dark road, where she fights back tears before getting sick. He carries her over his shoulder.

Later, in Sydney's apartment, he sits with his bespectacled father and Mrs. Kowalski. Alison, wearing Sydney's jacket, puts on music in his bedroom before dancing out to join them, earning a sidelong glance from Mrs. Kowalski. The white powder makes another appearance before Alison joins them on the sofa, eventually covering her mouth. The balding, brown-suited Richard stands as Mrs. Kowalski escorts Alison to Sydney's bedroom.

While Sydney cleans up, his father Richard returns a framed portrait of a woman to its shelf, his expression vacant. He approaches Sydney at the sink, almost touching his shoulder but hesitating before turning away. After placing his book on the table, father and son share a moment where Sydney's solemn expression reluctantly transforms into a smile.

Finally, Sydney checks on Alison, leaning against the doorframe to watch her sleep in the darkened room. His fond smile fades as she stirs, and his eyes dart anxiously before he withdraws from the doorway.
617:
In a crowded venue, she keeps her eyes fixed on the floor while he makes his exit, lifting his glass before turning away and adjusting his fangs as he disappears into the crowd. Alison stands with her back turned, while elsewhere, Sydney sits alone at a table, brooding over his goblet.

Vincent and Elena occupy the back seat of a car. As Elena lowers the window, Vincent leans forward. Sydney approaches the car window, his hands clasped near his chin, then steps back. Rain-soaked, he watches them as the window rises. Elena flashes a smile at the driver before they depart, leaving Sydney standing dejectedly by the roadside, hands still pressed together in a prayer-like gesture, his cape dragging in a puddle. Looking up, he spots Sophie on an electronic billboard, blowing him a kiss. Breathing heavily in the pouring rain, he drops his head.

The scene shifts to Clayton's office, where Sydney manages a smile. Later, at a sushi bar, Sydney, now professionally dressed in a pinstriped suit and dark glasses, eagerly takes notes while meeting with Vincent. Elena later reviews Sydney's article, making deletions before returning it to him. He accepts it with an appreciative nod. Sydney observes as Elena and a dark-haired colleague digitally edit Vincent's publicity photos, removing imperfections.

At a street corner kiosk, Sydney purchases Sharp's magazine, eagerly finding his published article, his face lighting up with joy. His career flourishes: his office accumulates gift baskets, he tours a spacious apartment with a realtor, receives an Omega Speedmaster watch (promptly discarding his old timepiece), and his name appears on numerous exclusive guest lists. He shares laughs with Clayton in the elevator, and later relaxes in a steam room, wearing white and sporting a satisfied smile.

Meanwhile, Alison reads about Sydney in a magazine while dining at a restaurant. Lawrence joins her, placing his arm around her shoulder and reading along, a white Russian cocktail on their table. He removes his arm, sips his drink, and leaves, while Alison returns to her novel with a troubled expression.

The story concludes at Sydney's apartment building, where Alison visits. Sydney, dressed in a striped robe, answers the door. As Alison acknowledges him, he leaves to retrieve some documents, prompting her to sigh and tilt her head back in resignation.
619:
Inside a school locker, photos and newspaper clippings cover the door. A girl drops papers from her folder as a boy passes, then grins watching her friend converse with a heavyset, bearded teacher. In class, Bleeker pops some Tic Tacs just as Juno approaches, clutching her folders. The scene grows busier as another boy joins them at the work table and a second girl appears. Amanda's departure leaves Josh speechless while Bleeker tries to hide his amusement.

Later, Juno makes a phone call, vigorously shaking the device until something dislodges. She frowns at it before suddenly vomiting into a decorative urn. At home, her little sister Liberty Bell sprinkles her food, offering a slow smile. Outside, Juno trudges past Su-Chin, briefly pausing before continuing toward the Women Now Center.

Inside, a punk receptionist plays her game console as Juno enters the lobby and approaches the counter. Following instructions, she takes a questionnaire to a leather bench. The atmosphere grows tense as she notices other women fidgeting - one crumbling her fingers against her clipboard, another painting nails, someone scratching, another filing - creating an overwhelming symphony of nervous habits until Juno drops her pen.

Su-Chin's mood lifts as they later sit together on a park bench, examining a newspaper. Leah passes a specific ad to pipe-smoking Juno. Meanwhile, Bleeker lies in his bed, studying Juno's yearbook photo with one hand while clutching fabric in the other. His stout, double-chinned mother shuts his bedroom door. Alone again, he returns to gazing at Juno's picture, retrieving his class pen from behind his head. The cloth he's holding reveals itself to be Juno's discarded underwear from their intimate encounter.

At Juno's house, Leah anxiously watches as Juno confronts her father and stepmother. Mac and Bren steel themselves as Juno meets their eyes. After Leah's grimace, Juno briefly lowers her head before speaking to her father's confused expression. She then bolts upstairs with Leah following, leaving Mac to bury his face in his hands.

Elsewhere, a slim young woman meticulously arranges white hydrangeas in a vase. Her white-cuffed hands adjust a glass photo frame before placing aromatic sticks in a bottle. She methodically fans out coffee table magazines, adjusts monogrammed tan towels, and wipes down a banister rail - her left hand's fourth finger bearing a ring. Meanwhile, Mac and Juno drive their blue Previa through the upscale Glacial Valley estate, passing numerous impressive houses set back from the road.
620:
The blue Previa slows down before a stately house, distinguished by its triple garage and a box tree adorning the front lawn, as its driver carefully parks in the driveway. Mac and Juno, dressed casually, approach the elegant double-fronted door, which stands between two slender fur trees. Mac conscientiously wipes his feet on the doormat before a well-groomed woman with long dark hair greets them with a warm smile.

The atmosphere shifts when Juno slaps Gerta's profit hand, causing Vanessa to purse her lips and fix Juno with an intense stare. As Juno ascends the staircase in her casual checked shirt and jeans, she passes a series of wedding photographs featuring Mark and Vanessa in white.

In Vanessa's luxurious en suite bathroom, Juno examines herself in the large mirror above the basin, adjusting her hair. The counter displays an array of expensive beauty products alongside a white orchid. Curiously, she samples the cream from one jar, applying it to her face before striking a playful bodybuilder pose. She then discovers a perfume bottle, testing it on her wrists. Upon leaving, she accidentally collides with Mark.

Her attention is drawn to a guitar, while Mac gestures toward some apparatus, eliciting a proud smile from Vanessa. When Mac's attempt at conversation meets confusion, they're all distracted by sounds from above. Vanessa, tall and slim, hurriedly ascends the stairs to find Mark and Juno performing a guitar duet. Meanwhile, Mac examines some paperwork.

As Mark closes the front door with a knowing smile, Vanessa seeks comfort in his embrace, pressing her hands together prayer-like. The scene shifts to a running track where Vijay accelerates past Bleeker, who slows to a walk as two boys overtake him.

At school, a stern-looking woman with grey hair, wearing a mauve cardigan, reluctantly signs a pink form for the visibly pregnant Juno. Later, during an ultrasound, a technician applies gel to Juno's swollen belly. Leah and Bren watch in wonder as shapes emerge on the monitor, though Bren's expression tightens. The technician exits with obvious disapproval.

Finally, in her art-decorated bedroom, Juno rests on her bed, legs elevated on cushions, contemplating the ultrasound image. Lost in thought, she soon finds herself driving Mac's blue Previa through Glacial Valley estate, where pristine houses stand amid snow-covered lawns.
624:
In a rural setting, a backyard features swings, a climbing frame, picnic table, and brick barbecue, overlooked by an upstairs window. Inside, a bedside photo captures a happy family - mother, father, and two children, with the father wearing a clerical collar.

Graham Hess, the man from the photo, suddenly awakens in bed, his eyes frantically scanning the modest bedroom before he regains composure. Now wearing a black t-shirt and pajama bottoms, the ruggedly handsome mid-40s man with short dark hair moves along the landing, pausing briefly at a door decorated with children's drawings. After listening momentarily, he retrieves some dropped socks and returns to his room. While brushing his teeth in the bathroom, he gazes out before checking the children's room.

Simultaneously, a younger man, Merrill, violently awakens in another rustic bedroom, tumbling from his bed and straining to hear something. Graham rushes from the farmhouse toward a white barn as Merrill descends the stairs. Together, they sprint through tall green maize until reaching a clearing, where they discover a six-year-old girl with dark hair, Bo, standing alone. Graham grabs her arms while Merrill lifts her up. Graham continues running, finding a ten-year-old boy, Morgan, staring vacantly across the field. When Graham tries to check on him, Morgan deliberately redirects his father's gaze.

Following Morgan's lead, Graham cautiously advances through the corn, with Merrill carrying Bo behind him. They emerge onto a massive circular expanse of flattened corn stalks, where two Alsatians nervously patrol the center. From above, the scene reveals two identical crop circles, each spanning roughly 100 yards, with one containing a small standing semicircle of maize within its boundary.
626:
In the dimly lit room, Graham examines a long, wide knife, turning it until he catches his own reflection in the polished steel blade. He moves to the door, angling the blade downward at its base while studying the various food containers reflected in its surface. After withdrawing the knife and setting it aside, he lies prone to peer under the door.

Reconsidering his approach, Graham retrieves the knife and rises to his knees, only to place it back on the worktop. He exits the room with determined steps, but quickly returns to grab the knife again before positioning himself on his stomach by the pantry door. Suddenly, a clawed hand shoots out from beneath the door, causing Graham to startle and bang his head, dropping the knife. Recovering quickly, he seizes the blade and slices off the creature's fingers. The violent action startles nearby birds, causing them to scatter from the maize fields into the sky.

Later, Graham returns to the farmhouse, carefully securing the door behind him and checking the handle before walking past the living room. He freezes at the sight before him: Bo, Morgan, and Merrill seated on the sofa, all wearing silver foil cone hats. Without reaction, Graham stiffly turns away and takes a seat on the stairs, while Merrill sits motionless, hands on knees. As Graham links his hands together, Merrill turns to Morgan, prompting a pained expression from Graham.

Wearily pulling himself up using the bottom stair post, Graham trudges into the living room toward the sofa. A silent interaction unfolds as Bo raises her arm, followed by Graham, then Morgan and Merrill. Graham regards them uncertainly as the others lower their arms and Morgan settles back into the sofa. After a moment's hesitation, Graham joins them, sitting beside his son. Morgan looks up at his father while Merrill stares ahead blankly before sighing.

The next day, in bright sunlight, Merrill emerges from his converted barn carrying a large white cotton sack. Cigarette in hand, he descends the grey-painted wooden stairs and crosses the lawn toward the farmhouse. Mid-stride, the maize field catches his attention. He discards his cigarette, slows to a stop, and abandons the sack to pick up a stone. With anxious anticipation, he hurls it into the field of maize and stands frozen, watching intently for any response.
627:
As storm winds buffet the shrubs outside the farmhouse, Merrill surveys the crops with suspicion before hastily retreating inside with a cotton sack. Inside, he finds Morgan and Bo transfixed by the television in the closet. Graham joins them, and together they watch the fearful presenter, Graham's unease visible as he stares unflinchingly at the screen. His features gradually sag with melancholy as he processes the presenter's words before wandering away, leaving Merrill to kneel beside the still-mesmerized children.

Morgan, pale with worry, briefly glances up at Merrill before returning his attention to the broadcast. Meanwhile, Graham moves through the house, methodically securing wooden planks over the windows until all outside light is blocked. Wind chimes clang ominously in the strengthening breeze outside.

In the dimly lit interior, Graham sits lost in thought while Merrill enters with Morgan and Bo, who position themselves against a wall. A series of subtle expressions cross Graham's face - nods, smiles, and finally a broad beam as he turns to look at his brother.

The kitchen counter tells the story of an abandoned meal preparation - stacked pans, empty eggshells in bowls, a sharp knife beside a skinned onion, and potato peelings atop tomatoes. The family sits in heavy silence around the dinner table. Graham shifts uncomfortably, his lips trembling, while Morgan's eyes appear swollen. The tension breaks as Graham begins eating ravenously, stabbing at molten toast while Merrill watches in disbelief. Bo sits beside him, tears streaming down her face.

As Graham's composure crumbles and he begins sobbing uncontrollably, Morgan rises to comfort his father. Graham embraces his son, then draws Bo to his other side. When his hand reaches out to include Merrill in the family embrace, his body continues to shake with emotion. The poignant scene is punctuated by the baby monitor's red lines beginning to flash at the table's end.
628:
In a tense sequence of events, Graham and his family find themselves frozen, staring upward with growing apprehension. Moving deliberately across the gleaming wooden floors, Graham makes his way to the front hallway, where he opens the cupboard beneath the stairs. Inside, he discovers a television set displaying a test card. After a nervous glance back at his family, he swallows hard.

The scene shifts as Merrill works upstairs, securing the children's bedroom by hammering boards across the door. Meanwhile, Graham cautiously approaches his bedroom window overlooking the maize field. What he sees causes his eyes to widen with fear, and he backs away toward the door. Under Merrill's watchful gaze, Graham edges out of the room, his eyes never leaving the window, and pulls the door shut behind him.

The brothers work together methodically, lifting planks and hammering them across the door frame while Bo and Morgan observe from the staircase. During their work, Graham pauses, his attention caught by Bo's presence. She remains still, holding tight to her brother before approaching. Graham crouches to her level, and when she shakes her head, he's met with her smile. Tenderly, he strokes her cheek before pulling her close and lifting her into his arms.

As Merrill continues fortifying the bedroom door, Graham carries Bo downstairs with Morgan following into the front hallway. After setting the children down, the family freezes, listening intently to dogs barking in the distance. Their attention is drawn to the wooden mantelpiece where two China dogs sit, dimly lit by wall lamps.

Graham's anxiety manifests in darting eyes and tightening fingers on Bo's shoulders as he and Merrill share worried looks. Their attention shifts between boarded windows, tracking shadows that dance across slivers of moonlight filtering through the planks. The family turns in unison, watching dark figures block the soft light seeping through gaps in the front window's boards.

Terror grips them as they pivot to face the kitchen's backdoor, then quickly return their attention to the front door, secured with a single plank. When the doorknob begins to turn, Morgan retreats in fear. Graham responds by placing a reassuring hand on his son's shoulder before kneeling before him. The scene culminates in an emotional moment as Graham offers a loving smile while tears stream down Morgan's face.
629:
In the dimly lit house, Merrill wearily ascends the first two steps of the staircase, only to discover with horror an unsecured hatch door in the attic. Together with Graham, he hastily escorts the children down the hallway into the kitchen. Morgan's face contorts with terror as ghostly green-gray fingers emerge beneath the front door.

Seeking refuge, Graham descends into the gloomy basement, slamming the door behind him. He presses his ear against the peeling olive-green door, hands braced against its surface. His attention draws to the doorknob as it begins to turn, and he desperately grips it with both hands, resting his forehead against the wood.

In the basement, Merrill spots and retrieves a pickaxe from a high shelf, accidentally shattering the light bulb and plunging the space into darkness. Morgan quickly illuminates their surroundings with a torch, examining it briefly before directing its beam toward the door. Graham and Merrill brace themselves against the entrance, securing the pickaxe beneath the doorknob while Graham positions himself with his back to the door, shielding his eyes from Morgan's bright beam.

As Morgan sweeps the torch around the cluttered basement, passing a workbench, the light reveals Bo crouched on the floor, offering a weak wave to her brother. Merrill, having found another flashlight, explores the basement's contents - wooden shelves lined with pickling jars, bowls, ski boots, roller skates, and various debris. He discovers an old radio and fiddles with its dial.

The group faces the door as Graham presses against it under Morgan's torch beam before turning to address the others. The pickaxe holds firm against the violent impacts. Morgan rolls his silver torch with its white head across to his father, and Merrill approaches Graham. They methodically circle the basement's rough stone walls, passing a dried, faded flower and wire-framed basket hanging on pegs.

As their paths converge again, their torch beams reveal Morgan standing before the coal chute's grill. Merrill and Graham freeze in horror as a clawed hand suddenly thrusts through the grill, seizing Morgan's throat. Graham drops his torch in his desperate rush to save his son, accidentally kicking it. The rolling torch illuminates Bo's legs beneath her silky blue dress as she cowers against the wall.
630:
In the dimly lit basement, the family huddles together in a tense scene. As she moves across the space, she illuminates Merrill with her torch while he fortifies their position, stacking crates and dog food sacks against the chute. Exhausted, he slumps down beside his makeshift barricade, only to notice a stray can of dog food which he wearily adds to the pile.

From his position on the floor, Merrill surveys the room with his torch, finding his brother Graham sitting against a pillar, holding Morgan protectively between his legs. Graham's hands rest firmly on his son's chest and shoulder as Morgan struggles to breathe, clutching his father's jeans desperately. Bo watches the scene with wide, frightened eyes before seeking comfort in Merrill's lap, tears forming.

As Morgan's breathing crisis intensifies, Graham's anger and helplessness show in his distant stare and quivering lips. Merrill, deeply concerned, silently prays while watching his nephew's ordeal. Gradually, Morgan's grip loosens as his breathing normalizes, and he relaxes against his father. The tension breaks as Merrill blinks rapidly, swallowing hard, and both he and Bo switch off their torches.

Graham's mind drifts to a painful memory: the accident scene where Caroline spoke to him, offering a bleak smile. He remembers walking past police officers surrounding a dejected Ray, whose pickup truck lay mangled against a tree as paramedics stood by.

Back in the basement, now illuminated by the main light, Graham looks up from his contemplation as Merrill approaches the radio. A shocking revelation appears to pass between the brothers, with Graham rising and moving toward Merrill in disbelief. Their tense exchange is marked by Graham's reflective glances and Merrill's accusatory stance, ending with Graham's numb acknowledgment.

Their attention turns to Morgan, now peacefully asleep on folded blankets. A sudden thought strikes Graham, who crouches beside his son and lifts his shirt, discovering with relief the baby monitor tucked into Morgan's back pocket.
632:
In an intense confrontation, Graham and the alien lock eyes, his gaze shifting between determined and tearful as memories of his conversation with Merrill flood back. The alien menacingly rocks back and forth, holding Morgan's limp body. Graham's tear-filled eyes scan the room, landing on a baseball bat mounted near Merrill. A silent understanding passes between the brothers as they notice the weapon.

The creature's sunken eyes glow an eerie green as it observes them. Without warning, it lowers its hand over Morgan's face, releasing a gray substance from its spike into the boy's nose. As Merrill grabs the bat, he launches into action, striking the alien's back with force. The creature drops Morgan, turning to face its attacker while Graham rushes to retrieve his son and the fallen syringe.

The battle intensifies as Merrill lands another blow to the alien's abdomen, sending it crashing into a side table. When water from an overturned glass splashes the creature, its skin erupts in an angry red wound. This revelation causes both men to notice the numerous water glasses scattered throughout the room. Graham looks at Bo in sudden understanding before rushing outside with Morgan, his daughter following close behind.

Through a broken window, Bo watches as Merrill continues the assault, swinging at glasses on the coffee table, each splash of water causing the alien to recoil in pain. Meanwhile, on the lawn, Graham carefully positions the syringe and injects it into Morgan's leg. Inside, Merrill delivers a powerful blow that sends the alien toppling backward, knocking over more glasses from a sideboard. Water cascades down, leaving the creature struggling for breath among shattered glass and the broken bat head.

As the alien takes its final labored breaths, its chest falling still, Merrill rushes outside to join his family. Graham cradles his unresponsive son, eyes closed in anguish, while Merrill checks Morgan's pulse and turns away in despair. Bo begins to sob, but suddenly Graham's eyes open, his face trembling with emotion. The family watches in amazement as Morgan lifts his head, alive and recovering from the ordeal.
633:
Through a series of mysterious crop circles, paths branch out in peculiar patterns, with one trail splitting into two prongs, while another formation features straight lines flanking a central maize circle, extending into three larger prongs pointing toward a smaller circle.

Graham stands at his window, phone in hand, before bowing his head and entering the kitchen, where he discovers one of the dogs lying near a puddle. As Morgan and Bo guide the Alsatian to the backyard, Graham tends to the mess, gathering paper towels to clean the urine from the floor. A dark-haired police officer, Carolyn, leans against the front hall doorway, watching Graham with weary eyes.

In the yard, Morgan tends to a smoking barbecue, turning chicken wings while one Alsatian observes from the veranda. The other dog, Houdini, lies listlessly as Bo kneels before him. Morgan joins his sister, sharing a large glass of water, which Bo then carefully pours into Houdini's metal bowl. The dog suddenly lifts his head toward Bo, causing her to jump back startled, while Morgan frowns at the unusual behavior. As Bo rises, Houdini follows suit, causing her to freeze in place.

The crop formation becomes more apparent, with all stalks aligned in one direction. Graham contemplates the scene, shaking his head while Caroline surveys the field. He walks deliberately toward the circle's edge as Caroline watches him, puzzled. Their observation is interrupted as they hurriedly emerge through the tall crops, anxiety evident in their movements. Graham spots something concerning and breaks into a run, with Caroline following close behind.

The scene reveals a tragic sight: Houdini lies lifeless near the climbing frame, a barbecue fork protruding from his throat. Morgan kneels beside the dog, clutching his asthma inhaler, his eyes red from crying as he looks up at his father. Above them, Bo perches on the climbing frame's platform, hugging her knees to her chest, dressed in blue sneakers and jeans beneath a pale flowery dress. As Morgan takes a puff from his inhaler, Graham crouches beside the fallen dog, his gaze fixed on his distressed son.
634:
In a somber moment, Morgan takes Graham's hand and steps over Houdini, their dead dog. As they both look down at the lifeless animal, Graham attempts to comfort his son with a hand on his shoulder, but Morgan shrugs it off and walks away, clearly grief-stricken.

Graham then turns his attention to Bo, who sits curled up tightly on the climbing frame, her eyes fixed downward. With gentle care, he lifts her from the platform and cradles her against his shoulder. As he carries her toward the farmhouse, Merrill - a boyish-looking man in his early thirties with short dark hair - emerges carrying feed supplies. Graham passes by silently, ascending the veranda and entering the house while Merrill gazes puzzled at the climbing frame.

Meanwhile, Merrill sets down his supplies and unleashes Isabel, their other Alsatian, from the veranda steps. As he guides her across the yard, Caroline removes the barbecue fork from Houdini's throat. A sun-shaped wire wind chime sways melancholically in the gentle breeze above the veranda.

As night falls, the farmhouse stands silent under the dark sky. Graham lies in bed until his eyes suddenly snap open, meeting Bo's watchful gaze. He takes her hand and leads her across the landing to the children's bedroom, where they find Morgan sprawled awkwardly half-off his bed. After carefully repositioning Morgan, Graham sits beside Bo on her bed, studying her intently. Her bright eyes meet his, and sadness crosses his features as he glances between his daughter and the bedroom window.

Suddenly, Graham spots a shadowy figure standing by a chimney pot on the barn roof and leaps to his feet. He rushes downstairs to the lounge, where he finds Merrill sleeping in an armchair. After waking his confused brother, they hurry to the front door. As they open it, an outside light illuminates the darkness.

The brothers split up to investigate - Merrill heading to the back of the house where he discovers an overturned dust bin, while Graham races along the side. They reconvene at the front, both breathless and alert. A noise from above draws their attention to the farmhouse roof, and Merrill backs slowly into the gloomy yard, keeping his eyes fixed upward as he tries to get a better view.
636:
As their silver station wagon cruises down the freeway past a modern church, Graham and his family begin their day in town. After parking among other vehicles by a strip of shops, Merrill tends to the parking meter while Graham hands some money to Morgan, who then takes Bo's hand as they walk down the sidewalk together. Graham watches his children's tender moment before calling out to Merrill, who heads off in the opposite direction.

The family splits up to run their errands. Morgan finds himself in a bookshop, absorbed in news coverage alongside the middle-aged owners. Meanwhile, Graham waits at the pharmacy counter, where a radio plays in the background. When the young assistant, Tracy, brings his prescription, her face crumples with emotion, leaving Graham visibly uncomfortable.

Merrill explores an army recruitment center, studying the posters before encountering Sergeant Cunningham, who sits at his desk beneath an Uncle Sam poster. Their interaction is marked by Merrill's apprehensive laughter as he receives a pamphlet. A scruffy young man named Lionel, wearing a sleeveless biker jacket, fills out forms nearby and smirks. Before leaving, Merrill, having pocketed the pamphlet, makes a threatening gesture that causes Lionel to flinch.

Back at the bookshop, Bo sits quietly sipping water as a cola commercial plays on TV, while Morgan presents a book to the shop lady. Later, the family reconvenes at a pizza restaurant, with Graham joining his already-eating family members. Their meal is interrupted when Graham spots a young Asian man through the doorway, opening the back of a brown Chevrolet 4x4. The entire family watches intently as the man notices their stares, his surprise evident. After Graham's deep breath, the unsettled young man hurriedly enters his vehicle and drives away, leaving Graham to return to his pizza while his family continues to gaze out at the street.
639:
Late at night, Morgan retrieves a video, setting in motion an intense viewing session. Graham watches the screen with wide-eyed attention as Morgan, now seated and using his inhaler, joins Merrill on the sofa. Bo takes her place next to her father, completing their family gathering. All four become entranced by the television, where two glasses of water sit atop.

As night deepens and the lights dim, Graham and Merrill remain fixated on the screen while the children drift off to sleep. A series of meaningful glances passes between the brothers - Merrill's smile fading into solemnity, Graham's expression growing increasingly somber. Merrill appears uneasy, then brightens momentarily as a memory surfaces, offering a slight grin. Their silent communication continues through knowing looks and subtle nods, their emotions shifting between forlorn contemplation and intense conviction. Finally, with features taut and eyes glistening, Graham turns back to the TV, followed by Merrill, both watching in an almost trance-like state.

The scene shifts to a flashback: Graham, looking fresh-faced and wearing his priest's collar, drives down a dark country road, encountering emergency vehicle lights and Caroline frantically waving her arms. He stops to meet her, his expression grave.

Returning to the present, Graham awakens on the sofa in the sunlit room, his eyes glazed. After remaining motionless for a while, he notices a black cable across the polished floor. Following it to a closet under the stairs, he discovers Merrill, bleary-eyed and transfixed by the TV. Their awkward encounter ends with Graham's hasty retreat and the closing door.

Later, Graham, now in a blue dressing gown, emerges from the bathroom toweling his ear. He pauses to survey the empty garden with its playground equipment and picnic bench. Hearing voices, he investigates the children's room, finding Morgan and Bo sitting on a bed, wearing homemade silver foil cone hats. Morgan holds an open book as Bo gestures to her hat. Graham joins them, settling between his children and examining Morgan's book before the child closes it.
64:
The encounter comes to an abrupt halt. Struggling against the current, he manages to drag himself from the rushing water using the fence as leverage. Soaked and bruised, he laboriously climbs back over and trudges toward his vehicle. As he searches for his keys, he notices one shoe is missing.

Before he can enter his car, Mulvihill and a smaller accomplice intercept him. Mulvihill immobilizes him by pulling down his coat and pinning his arms. The situation turns violent as the smaller man produces a switchblade, forcing it an inch and a half into Gittes' left nostril. Time seems to freeze as the street lamp's light glints off the blade. With brutal efficiency, the smaller man jerks the knife, tearing Gittes' nostril another inch. His scream pierces the night as blood cascades onto his clothing.

Instinctively, Gittes doubles over, trying futilely to protect his clothes from the blood. His attackers watch impassively as he collapses to his hands and knees. From this humiliating position, all he can see are his assailant's two-tone wing-tips, now speckled with his blood. A final shove forces him to the ground, followed by the sound of retreating footsteps as he gasps for air.

Later, at his office, Gittes sits motionless at his desk, facing away from the room. While Duffy stares blankly and Walsh paces restlessly, Gittes slowly turns to Walsh and gently touches his injured nose, showing irritation. He reaches for the phone as Walsh launches into the Admiral Byrd story, drawing raucous laughter from both men. Gittes sorts through mail, then suddenly silences them with a hand over the receiver.

In another scene, Gittes scans a newspaper, focusing intently on the obituaries before abruptly tearing out the column and pocketing it. Evelyn Mulwray appears, elegantly dressed in dove gray gabardine, as he rises to offer her a seat. A waiter approaches as she studies his injured nose, then smooths her gloves nervously before meeting his gaze expectantly.

Gittes produces a torn envelope, fidgeting with it as he coughs and smiles meaningfully at her. Though clearly angry, Evelyn maintains her composure, which somewhat tempers Gittes' demeanor. Her initial heat gives way to embarrassment as she looks him straight in the eye. He acknowledges with a nod, still handling the envelope. The scene concludes with Evelyn turning toward him as he leans into her car door, delivering his message in a quiet but forceful tone.
642:
Jamal and Latika's eyes meet in an intense gaze before a guard disrupts the moment, pressing the intercom and moving to open the gates. Latika quickly retreats inside while Jamal follows, entering an opulent marble living room. Through a glass partition separating the kitchen, he spots Latika, who removes her dark sunglasses as he approaches. They stand frozen, the air electric between them. After a sharp intake of breath, Latika's face breaks into a smile, and they rush into a tight embrace.

Their reunion is cut short when fear suddenly crosses Latika's face, causing her to back away. A silver Mercedes arrives outside, and as Javed enters, Latika hastily places an apron around Jamal's neck. Javed stalks into the kitchen, fixing Latika with a menacing stare before gesturing to the TV. He settles into the living room, switching to a cricket match.

In the kitchen, tension mounts as Latika nervously prepares Javed's sandwich while Jamal spreads condiments and she adds wilted lettuce. Their eyes meet in anxious exchange before he desperately grabs her hand. Breaking free, she delivers the plate to Javed, who dismissively waves her away when she crosses his view of the game. Frustrated with the match, Javed hurls his drink, while Jamal looks at Latika imploringly. After taking one bite, Javed spits out the sandwich in disgust, storming into the kitchen to glare at Jamal before returning to his cricket match, muttering curses.

Latika urgently guides Jamal toward the exit, slowly shaking her head before pushing him out. He lingers in the courtyard, watching her, before tilting his face skyward with a deep breath. As cricket match replays flash by, Jamal firmly returns the check to the host.

Later, aboard a train racing through the city, Jamal gazes out the window until reaching a bustling station. He disembarks among hundreds of passengers, watching an enormous clock tick from 4:55 to 5:15. Moving along the walkway above the platforms, he desperately searches the crowds below before sinking into despair. Suddenly, Latika appears on the platform, anxiously scanning her surroundings. Jamal spots her immediately, springing to his feet as she continues her nervous search.
646:
In the midst of violent riots, a terrifying scene unfolds as Jamal's mother screams at her sons before being brutally clubbed in the face by attackers, who are mercilessly bludgeoning defenseless civilians. She falls backward into the water as the boys scramble out of the pool. Though Jamal looks back desperately for his mother, who lies face down in the pool, Salim urgently pushes him forward.

Chaos erupts around them as they flee through the streets. They witness a man being trampled by a violent mob and another throwing a Molotov cocktail at a door. In their desperate escape, they suddenly encounter a young boy dressed as the Hindu god Rama, covered in blue paint with bound-up hair and wielding a bow and arrow. The brothers freeze momentarily before continuing their flight.

As they run, they pass a girl named Latika hiding in an alley. The violence escalates - a man bursts into the street, his clothes ablaze. Despite reaching a police station, they find the officers indifferently playing cards, completely ignoring the chaos outside. The brothers continue running, gesturing for Latika to follow as she struggles to keep up.

From high ground, five-year-old Jamal and Salim watch their slum burn in the riots, with Latika standing at a distance. Later, during a torrential downpour, Latika stands alone in the rain while the brothers take shelter. Jamal observes her tracing letters in puddles before calling out to her. She joins them in their shelter, and all three children lie shivering together, with Salim remaining awake, his eyes wide open.

Years later, these memories surface as Jamal sits on a studio stage opposite a host. The scene shifts to a massive garbage dump where people scavenge through mountains of rotting refuse. Latika picks through scraps with a stick until a minibus arrives, causing her to look up and shout. Two men approach a makeshift tent where Jamal and Salim lie dozing among the rubbish.
647:
In a dilapidated residence surrounded by playing children, Maman kneels to stroke Salim's foot before the boy wakes. He offers Salim a Coke, then does the same for Jamal, patting him on the back with a smile. The boys eagerly drink, sitting in a minibus filled with scruffy street kids gazing at the lush countryside passing by. When they arrive, the compound bustles with children of all ages - some on crutches, others enjoying swings - as Salim and his fellow passengers react with excitement.

Maman observes the children during their hot meal, his gaze particularly fixed on the newcomers, which Jamal notices. That evening, Maman assembles the new arrivals, listening intently to Arvind's performance before patting his head. When Salim steps forward to sing, Maman reacts with disgust, burying his head in his hands. Violence erupts as he strikes Latika and punches Punnoose's thighs, prompting widespread laughter.

The following day, Salim and Punnoose observe a group of street children from their bus. Salim approaches them aggressively, clapping his hands and slapping a giggling child while Jamal watches. The situation escalates when Salim snatches a baby, taunting Latika by pretending to drop it. Soon after, the children - some with missing hands or using crutches - scatter into the busy street, begging for money. Latika, wearing an eye patch, solicits from stopped cars.

At midnight in Maman's compound, a mischievous plan unfolds. Following Jamal's guidance, Latika, wearing rubber gloves, crushes dried chillies and sneaks into the dormitory. She carefully places the crushed chillies on the sleeping, naked Salim's groin, while Punnoose sleeps nearby. Upon returning to her side, Salim suddenly awakens and rushes to douse himself with cold water. As Punnoose wakes and points at Latika, she and Jamal share a knowing laugh.

The scene takes a darker turn as Arvind performs for Maman by candlelight, lit by a bearded henchman. Maman signals, and Punnoose quickly subdues Arvind with a chemical-soaked cloth. Salim watches in horror as Arvind's unconscious body is placed on a table. As Salim follows orders, the bearded man heats a mysterious liquid over the candle flame.
651:
In a tense confrontation, the boys burst into the room where Latika stands, her eyes meeting Jamal's dumbfounded gaze with a smile of recognition. At the doorway looms Maman, flanked by his henchmen, his enforcer Punnoose's face bearing terrible scars. Though Latika avoids Maman's gaze, she remains still until he roughly seizes her. The situation escalates dramatically when Salim produces a revolver from behind his back, training it on the men while Jamal watches his brother in astonishment. As Maman inches closer, leering at Salim, the latter places a cushion over his weapon. Jamal recoils in horror as the men tremble. Latika seizes the moment to snatch Maman's money from the floor while Jamal stands paralyzed. The three children make their escape.

Years later on the game show, Jamal appears lost in thought as the host mimics holding a gun, triggering memories of Maman's death. As the host checks his computer screen, Jamal's mind drifts to another memory: the night the three children snuck past a sleeping guard into an empty luxury hotel, racing up through a defunct elevator to an atrium adorned with an enormous gold chandelier.

In their commandeered room, Salim jubilantly mixes spirits in a pot while Jamal retrieves a dusty towel from a cupboard, taking it to the bathroom door. After taking a swig of beer, Salim's mood suddenly shifts, and he departs. Outside, he traverses a bustling street filled with various vehicles, purchases a cinema ticket, and makes his way to a balcony where six men are engrossed in gambling. Unnoticed, Salim approaches them, draws his gun, and aims it at one man's head. Upon seeing Javed, Salim turns and nods, receiving a beckoning gesture in return.

Meanwhile, back in the hotel room, Jamal and Latika share an intimate moment on a floor mattress. She creates elegant hand shadows on the wall, her arms adorned with intricate gold and henna patterns. They gaze at each other intently until Salim's return interrupts their peaceful repose. Standing over the now-awakened pair, Salim extends his hand toward Latika. When Jamal charges at him, Salim overpowers his smaller brother and forces him out of the room, emerging afterward with his gun drawn.
655:
As chaos erupts, the balcony begins to crumble, forcing Peter to act swiftly, shooting webs to rescue two bystanders from falling debris. MJ finds herself trapped on a precarious section of the swaying balcony while Peter, spotting the danger, rushes through the crowd, frantically pulling at his clothes to reveal the Spider-Man costume underneath.

The situation intensifies as a massive pillar crushes a police vehicle below. The Green Goblin returns on his glider, unleashing a devastating pumpkin bomb that incinerates the board members. In the mayhem, Harry is struck unconscious by falling masonry. As the Goblin ascends, Spider-Man launches a counter-attack, kicking him off his glider onto a marquee. The unmanned glider pierces through a hot air balloon, emerging on the other side.

A young boy stands frozen in terror as the World Unity Festival hoarding threatens to crush him, but Spider-Man intervenes just in time. When police attempt to apprehend the Green Goblin, he effortlessly dispatches them with powerful punches. Spider-Man swings in to confront him, but the Goblin catches his punch and delivers a devastating kick, sending Spider-Man crashing into a lamp post, which unfortunately falls onto a passerby.

The Goblin reclaims his weapon-equipped glider and pursues Spider-Man, firing relentlessly. Spider-Man narrowly dodges a missile by leaping onto an inflatable. Hearing MJ's desperate screams, he bounces from inflatable to inflatable, using one shaped like a kangaroo as a springboard. Just as he approaches the balcony, the Goblin ambushes him from behind, violently smashing him against stained glass windows. Spider-Man breaks free after elbowing his attacker and they engage in an intense fight until Spider-Man falls toward MJ.

As the Goblin descends, Spider-Man blinds him with webbing and disables the glider by removing an electric cell. In the chaos, MJ loses her grip and plummets. Spider-Man dives after her, catching her mid-fall, and uses a web attached to the balcony to spring them both to safety, landing her among the relieved crowds above.

Their journey continues high above Manhattan's streets, with MJ clinging tightly to Spider-Man, mesmerized by both the experience and her mysterious savior. They soar past St. Patrick's Cathedral's twin spires before landing at Rockefeller Center's roof garden, startling a romantic couple. Spider-Man bids farewell with a dramatic somersault off the roof, leaving MJ to watch in amazement as he swings through the city streets below.
657:
In a poignant moment, she tenderly cups his face and they share a lingering kiss beneath the falling rain. After their intimate exchange, she carefully adjusts his mask back into position.
