The men depart, with Dillinger emerging alone, dressed in a black vest and leather holster without his overcoat. The woman stops him briefly - their eyes meet in an intense exchange before she releases him. As he walks away, she and a small boy in overalls step forward together, watching his retreating figure. In the car, Dillinger glances between Red at the wheel and Pete in back.

The scene shifts dramatically as a man in a blue suit, clutching a Tommy gun, frantically races through verdant woods. Despite stumbling, he presses on, pursued by a clean-cut man in suspenders carrying a rifle, with armed lawmen charging behind them up the hill. The outlaw, Floyd, descends into an apple orchard as his pursuer, reaching the hilltop, takes aim. Floyd fires backwards wildly, missing his mark, and continues fleeing. The lawman kneels calmly, carefully adjusting his rifle's triggers as Floyd sprints between the trees. The shot strikes true, tearing through Floyd's abdomen and dropping him to the grass.

The lawman and his team approach the fallen outlaw. Floyd attempts to draw a pistol, but the lawman swiftly kicks it away and trains his rifle on him. Purvis maintains an unwavering gaze as Floyd bleeds through his white shirt, his throat muscles spasming before going still. The lawmen lower their weapons as Purvis examines the dead man, gives his men a confirming nod, and shoulders his rifle, his expression tightening.

The Nash sedan comes to a halt as, elsewhere, a woman folds a newspaper in an immaculate white kitchen.
913:
At a quiet table, two women pass the time - one writing, the other gazing through the window. A burly man wearing suspenders anxiously peers through the blinds before hastily departing. Outside, Dillinger and his crew emerge from their vehicle, greeted by a young blonde woman who receives a charming grin and kiss from Dillinger before they all head indoors.

The scene shifts to a garage where Dillinger observes a gunsmith methodically taking apart a Tommy gun, removing its trigger handle and coil. Two cars pull up outside the window as Red exits the safe house. Following a subtle nod from the blonde, Dillinger rises and departs, tossing keys to Pete who joins Red to inspect the new vehicles.

Moving through the house, Dillinger enters the kitchen where a man leans against the refrigerator and a woman smokes at the table. After washing his hands, he hands the man a stuffed envelope, circles the table, and tenderly kisses the woman's cheek before departing.

The heist begins as three fedora-clad men in overcoats climb a grand staircase, separated by twin railings. At the summit, Dillinger surveys the angular bank interior with its impressive pillared walls. His companions disperse as Pete violently subdues a guard with strikes to the face and gut. Dillinger, Tommy gun in hand, vaults over a counter with fluid grace, seizing a middle-aged man - the bank president - by his collar.

Parading the president across the floor past a trembling customer, Dillinger roughly guides him to a metal gate while his accomplices busy themselves collecting cash from tellers. When the president fumbles with keys, Dillinger strikes him with a pistol and threatens him further. Tellers frantically stuff cash into bags as Pete maintains control from atop a counter.

Outside, Homer discreetly positions himself with a rifle near double doors, spotting an approaching police car. Inside, Dillinger supervises the president filling a sack with the safe's contents while Red checks his pocket watch before driving off in a getaway car. As police rush toward the bank, Red's car approaches while Homer watches carefully. In a final moment, Dillinger, still controlling the president, notices some change on a counter and turns his attention to its owner.
914:
In a violent confrontation outside a bank, Homer takes brutal action, striking a police officer with his rifle before using him as a human shield while returning fire. Inside, a female teller rushes to join Dillinger as they descend the stairs. The situation intensifies as Homer engages in a firefight, shooting at a police vehicle just as reinforcements arrive.

Red maintains his position in the getaway car while his accomplices emerge with four hostages. Down the street, law enforcement officers take defensive positions, training their rifles over their vehicle's hood. Dillinger's gang strategically uses their hostages as protection while moving toward their escape vehicle, with Dillinger himself aiming his weapon past the president's shoulder. After an officer initiates gunfire, Homer and Dillinger respond with devastating effect, their automatic weapons taking down several lawmen.

The getaway car tears away from the scene, Dillinger and Homer perched on the running boards alongside their hostages, their overcoats billowing in the wind. Under a bridge, they pause briefly. Dillinger confronts Homer's hostage before releasing two captives. Noticing the young female teller shivering, Dillinger shows an unexpected gesture of kindness, wrapping his coat around her and helping her into the backseat before Red drives on.

Inside the vehicle, Dillinger offers the teller his hat as they travel down a dirt path toward a barren forest. Homer takes position next to the young teller while Pete breaks into laughter. Deep in the woods, they secure the bank president and teller to a tree before making their final escape in their vehicle.

The scene shifts to a formal hearing room, where Director Hoover faces a congressional committee. A mustached senator engages him directly while Hoover confers with his bespectacled assistant. Accompanied by Suydam and a slender young man, Hoover exits purposefully. In the hallway, Suydam documents their conversation as Hoover addresses his young colleague.

Later, Purvis contemplates quietly near a fedora resting on a burgundy leather couch. Upon Hoover's emergence from his office, Purvis rises, and they traverse the FBI bullpen together before stepping onto a sun-lit veranda crowded with reporters. After Hoover addresses the microphone, he gestures for Purvis to take over, who faces the press with determination.

The final scene unfolds in Dillinger's supper club, where he dines contentedly with companions. He periodically checks his watch and the entrance while observing a brunette in red dancing nearby. His attention is eventually drawn to Alvin, a thin man wearing glasses, who approaches. Dillinger rises to greet him, and Alvin joins him at the table, leaning in for a private conversation.
92:
Cautiously, she slides the paper sack in his direction. As he peers inside, he discovers the bottom teeming with plump, writhing earthworms.

In an empty parking lot stands Marge's prowler. Inside a deserted club, not yet open for business, Marge engages in conversation with two young women at one end of a raised dance platform. The scene ends with a resounding bang.

A microscopic drama unfolds as an insect struggles with a worm. The camera pulls back to reveal Marge and Norm in their bedroom, watching television together. After a prolonged silence broken only by the TV's drone, Marge murmurs something while groping in the darkness.

Jerry sits numbly before grabbing his phone in frustration, then returns to eating. Gary presents a flimsy document to Marge, who accepts it while frozen mid-bite. Norm, having eaten continuously, glances at Marge with mild curiosity, finishing his mouthful before speaking.

Under harsh overhead lighting, Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman gather around a kitchen table adorned with coffee remnants and a partially eaten cinnamon filbert ring. Meanwhile, at a reception desk, Marge watches a clerk typing into a computer before making a call from a public phone.

A brown Ciera weaves through the snow-covered cars on a parking lot's roof. Carl exits the vehicle, surveys the area, and kneels to remove a parked car's license plate. Later, he presents his ticket to a confused attendant, eventually resorting to counting out dollar bills. Bewildered, he seeks directions from a passing mechanic over the workshop noise.

Jerry stares and swallows hard while Marge and Shep engage in silent conversation within a grimy, glass-enclosed office space. After their wordless exchange, Jerry paces anxiously behind his desk until Marge appears in the doorway. She settles into the chair across from him, leaving Jerry slack-jawed. As she departs, he stares blankly at his desk papers.

Finally, Marge enters a dimly lit, unremarkable bar frequented by business people. A middle-aged, bald, paunchy man rises from a booth halfway back to greet her.
926:
Clutching a metal case, he exits and spots a small car whipping around the corner. After a moment's hesitation, he notices her handbag and discreetly opens it. A moped rider appears behind them as the woman dangerously weaves through traffic, causing chaos and forcing their pursuer to halt. The attractive brunette with high cheekbones steers her small car into an alley, leaving their follower confused about their whereabouts.

She makes a seductive pout while gesturing toward the case. As they examine the papers, which turn out to be blank, the moped rider continues searching. The situation escalates when he grabs her wrist mid-shot. As their pursuer closes in, he leaps from the vehicle, confronts the approaching rider, skillfully dismounts him with a flip, delivers a swift kick to his face, and commandeers the bike.

Bond maintains a calculated distance, following the girl's bronze car several vehicles behind. They arrive at a bustling quay where cargo vessels are being unloaded. The woman angrily storms past a guard wearing dark glasses, while Bond, arriving on his motorcycle, notices another guard in a floral shirt armed with a sub-machine gun.

Inside an office, as an official stamps documents, she confronts a Frenchman while a nervous German-speaking man looks on. A corpse floats beneath the quay as a powerful speedboat approaches. After presenting credentials to the guard and acknowledging a security camera, Bond departs. The German, wearing square shades, examines a Universal Exports card while Bond activates his phone's tracking feature.

Approaching a heavyset general with a distinctive bushy mustache, he presents a map which the general accepts with a nod while eyeing the Frenchman. The girl glares at the scene before being summoned and roughly grabbed by a burly hand. Bond observes this with concern before departing on his motorcycle.

Camille is escorted to the speedboat as Bond navigates the busy docks, standing on his saddle for a better view. Dominic offers a mocking farewell as the boat carrying Camille departs, while she returns a sultry, hate-filled glare. Bond executes a dramatic sequence, jumping his bike onto boats, across crates, before abandoning it to pursue the launch heading toward a luxury cruiser.

Racing across merchandise-laden vessels, Bond commandeers a small launch with an outboard motor to shadow the general's boat. He rams it deliberately, while Dominic watches in shock as armed crew members from the cruise ship scramble into an inflatable. In the ensuing chaos, Bond boards the launch, and when Camille reaches for a weapon, he swiftly disarms her, knocking the gun into the water before pulling her into his boat.
930:
In an intimate moment, Mathis hands Bond an envelope before the agent, his hair disheveled, sets down his champagne and retreats to the bedroom. There, a tender scene unfolds as he kisses his companion's bare back, her smile turning toward him before he pulls her onto the bed.

The evening transitions to an elegant party under a full moon, with a DJ providing entertainment while servers circulate with cocktails and hors d'oeuvres. Bond arrives in a Range Rover with Fields, who's stunning in a black and gold dress. As he navigates through the sophisticated crowd, exchanging handshakes, CIA agent Felix observes from his position on a sofa.

The couple finds themselves at a stone balustrade, where their passionate kiss ends with Bond forcefully pushing her against the weathered stonework. A thin German appears, Fields passes by, and the CIA men gather together.

Events take a darker turn as Bond returns to the Range Rover, fastening his seatbelt as motorcyclists begin tailing them. After parking, two motorcycle officers pull up behind them. One officer, peculiarly wearing sunglasses at night, requests Bond's license. The situation escalates when the officer draws his weapon upon opening it.

The grim discovery of Mathis in the trunk leads to a violent confrontation. Bond efficiently dispatches the officers, using one's weapon against the other before discarding it. He pulls Mathis's unconscious form from the trunk, cradling him as Camille watches. After Mathis's head falls against Bond's shoulder and Bond confirms his death with an emotionless pulse check, he disposes of the body in a dumpster, taking only the cash from Mathis's wallet before abandoning it.

The journey continues as the Range Rover traverses a desert highway under M's cold gaze, eventually reaching a small airstrip. There, they encounter a man in a leather jacket and brimmed hat, who notices Bond adjusting his jacket to hide a bloodstain. Bond surveys an old DC-3 Dakota as Camille exits the vehicle.

The aging transport plane takes off, stirring dust clouds in its wake, while the man in the hat makes a phone call. Suddenly, a fighter jet appears, forcing Bond into evasive maneuvers. He pilots the plane into a desperate dive as the fighter attempts to get behind them, then descends into a valley. With Camille visibly concerned, Bond maintains intense focus as they skim dangerously close to the valley floor. He deploys the landing gear for a rough touchdown before accelerating again, while the fighter jet pursues them through the narrow valley, barely avoiding the rocky terrain. In the midst of this chaos, Fields moves through the plane's fuselage.
936:
After freeing Holmes from a meat hook in his shoulder, Watson helps his injured companion across the factory floor, past rows of waiting Howitzers. The pair quickly arm themselves - Watson with a machine gun, Holmes with a pistol - as Watson takes point.

Meanwhile, in the ruins, Moran manages to extract Moriarty from the debris. Sim spots Holmes and Watson, rushing ahead of them just as Holmes notices approaching guards. Watson immediately opens fire, providing cover as Sim and her gypsy companions lead the evacuation from the factory. During a brief pause to reload, Holmes takes down a guard before following the others into a rail yard.

The escape turns violent when the rough-looking twins kill one of the gypsies, but Holmes and Watson swiftly eliminate both attackers. The group reaches the rail yard's perimeter wall and throws a rope over it, but guard gunfire forces them to seek shelter. Watson returns fire with his machine gun, though the guards' Gatling gun response drives the fugitives behind crates for protection.

When a massive artillery piece targets their position, its shell overshoots, inadvertently blasting an escape route through the perimeter wall. The group flees into the woods, where a train approaches on distant tracks. The guard captain mobilizes his men through the breach in pursuit.

As guards fire through the trees and launch mortar rounds, explosions erupt around the fleeing group. Moran joins the pursuit, wounding Watson with a rifle shot to his right flank. Despite the injury, Watson continues running as bullets tear into surrounding trees. Holmes manages to fell one guard with his pistol while massive explosions rock the forest and Sims sprints ahead. The pursuit intensifies, and Moran claims another victim, shooting down one of the gypsies as Sims continues her desperate flight.

Back at the artillery position, the fearsome Little Hansel is prepared for action. The crew methodically loads a massive shell into the breach, adjusts the barrel elevation, and adds the powder charge. After final elevation adjustments, the gun crew chief gives the command to fire.
937:
With a mechanical clank, the lever is pulled and the ratchet releases, igniting the powder charge. The massive artillery piece unleashes a tremendous fireball from its muzzle, recoiling with such force that it blasts a crew member's hat clean off. The shell tears through the forest, demolishing one tree before narrowly missing Holmes and obliterating another. The projectile detonates ahead, creating a devastating explosion that fills the air with lethal wooden shrapnel and sends the fleeing group sprawling.

As the guards advance, Holmes lies momentarily incapacitated by the blast. Dirt sprinkles onto his face as he regains consciousness, and both he and Watson struggle to their feet. Watson immediately engages a guard while Moran rushes toward the escalating melee. In the chaos, a gypsy shoots down one guard just as another mortar explosion rocks the ground near Holmes. Leaning against a tree for support, Holmes faces an attacking guard whose bullet strikes the tree before attempting a bayonet thrust. Holmes counters with a punch, disarms the guard, reloads the weapon, and passes it to Watson, who shoots Moran as he crests a rise.

The survivors - Holmes, Watson, Sim, and the remaining gypsies - make a desperate dash for a nearby train, clambering into a boxcar. Meanwhile, Moran recovers, examining his wound before methodically preparing his rifle. Taking careful aim after several steadying breaths, he fatally shoots one of the gypsies attempting to board, leaving the victim's companions to watch helplessly as they leave their fallen comrade behind. Moran can only stare as the train carries his quarry to safety.

The railway track snakes through a wooded valley before emerging onto a snow-blanketed plain, bordered by jagged mountains in the dawn light. Inside the boxcar, Sim cradles Holmes while Watson tends to his own wound. Holmes' condition deteriorates rapidly - his eyes close and he becomes completely unresponsive, causing mounting concern among his companions. Watson frantically performs chest compressions, but Holmes shows no signs of life despite repeated attempts at resuscitation. As Sim pulls a devastated Watson away, consoling him with an embrace while a gypsy offers a sympathetic pat, Watson has a sudden realization. He retrieves the leather pouch Holmes had given him earlier, extracting a vial and hypodermic needle. In a final desperate act, Watson drives the needle directly into Holmes' chest.
939:
As Watson observes Moriarty's departure, a photographer prepares nearby. On a balcony, Holmes sips from his hip flask when a mysterious stumbling sound echoes in the darkness. Moriarty emerges to join him, retrieving a chess timing clock which he places beside a chessboard. After Holmes takes his seat, Moriarty thoughtfully drapes blankets over both their shoulders. They share a brief smile before Moriarty's expression turns stern. He initiates the game by moving a white pawn and setting the clock.

Inside, Watson and Sim navigate through the guests while Holmes and Moriarty continue their strategic duel on the balcony, with Holmes advancing a black pawn. The pair inside reconvenes to observe the delegates just as Holmes captures one of Moriarty's pawns with his knight, prompting Moriarty to counter with a bishop move.

As a man smokes his cigar, Sim scrutinizes potential assassins. A deadly hyperemic needle lies concealed within a modified Winchester cartridge case. Watson, noting the photographer preparing for the delegates' photo, deliberately creates a distraction by knocking over a servant's drink tray. The crash draws everyone's attention except one suspicious man in the corner, who drops his cigar. Watson notices his hairline while Sim observes him stepping away from a delegate. They exchange knowing glances.

The situation escalates when the suspect reaches into his jacket. As Sim approaches him, he violently pushes her aside and draws his weapon. Watson's quick intervention prevents the shot from finding its mark, and Mycroft springs into action as soldiers apprehend the would-be assassin. Meanwhile, another conspirator prepares the hyperemic cartridge, which Moran craftily uses to shoot Rene through a concealed gun in his cane as the soldiers drag him away.

Watson's sudden realization sends him running to join Rene's guards, finding him collapsed and convulsing. Examining the victim, Watson discovers and extracts a hyperemic dart from Rene's leg, testing the compound as Moran watches with satisfaction. Sim rushes to Rene's side while Watson notices Moran's departure, but must attend to the rapidly fading Rene.

Back on the balcony, an unsettled Holmes appears troubled, settling back in his chair. Moriarty removes his blanket and rises to the table while Holmes, also discarding his blanket, studies the chessboard intently. The scene concludes with Moriarty touching his notebook, running his thumb across its top line.
94:
Jerry's intense stare at her suddenly erupts into rage as he leaps to his feet, furiously grabbing his parka from behind the open door and snatching up his galoshes before storming out. Marge maintains a long, steady gaze before finally breaking her stare to pull a clipboard closer, examining a General Motors Finance Corporation form. Her eyes wander around the office, landing on another picture of Jean, then inexplicably drifting to the ceiling before resuming their idle scan. Her attention suddenly fixes as Jerry makes a left turn into traffic, prompting her to quickly grab the phone and dial.

Meanwhile, Grimsrud remains silent as a disgusted Carl pockets his gun and heads for the door. As Carl walks toward his car, the cabin door creaks open behind him. Hearing the sound, Carl turns to see Grimsrud bounding out, wearing mittens and a red hunter's cap but no overcoat, wielding an axe. In one brutal motion, Grimsrud swings the axe overhead, embedding it in Carl's neck.

In her cruiser, Marge listens to Lou's filtered voice through the two-way radio as she approaches a short driveway leading to a cabin, where a brown Cutlass Ciera sits parked out front. When Grimsrud stares, she deliberately displays her shoulder patch insignia. Suddenly, Grimsrud grabs a log, hurls it at her, and flees. Marge twists away defensively as Grimsrud laboriously pants up the hill through deep snow.

Now captured, Grimsrud sits in the back of the police car, his sunken cheeks and hollow eyes sourly fixed on the road ahead. Marge occasionally checks him in the rearview mirror as his head bobs with the road's bumps, his scowling expression unchanged. She appears to be talking to herself as she drives through the snowy landscape before finally pulling over, her utilities creaking and jangling as she leans back.

Outside, snow blankets everything in white - sky, earth, and road. As Marge stares ahead and shakes her head, emergency vehicles pierce through the whiteness in slow motion: first a squad car with spinning lights, followed by an ambulance, then another police car. On a windswept, snowy plain beside a highway stands a building with a few cars and an idling police cruiser in its lot. Two uniformed officers flank the door, hands resting on their holstered weapons. One raps on the door while the other draws his gun and signals to someone entering from behind.
940:
Holmes envisions the impending confrontation in his mind: a thug checking a pocket watch while brandishing a knuckleduster, another wielding a knife, a third with his own knuckleduster, and one more clutching a club. Their leader, armed with a gun, signals his men with a menacing throat-cutting gesture.

As the scene unfolds in reality, Holmes springs into action. A blond thug casually tosses an apple through the air. Moving with calculated precision, Holmes deflects a knife thrust, manipulating the attacker so his blade finds another assailant instead. He swiftly dispatches the club-wielding man, then disarms their leader of his gun. With a display of casual mastery, Holmes catches the falling apple and tosses it to the now-helpless leader. After emptying the weapon and returning it, he feints at the cowering leader before jogging away.

At Cromwell and Griff auctioneers, Irene Adler delivers a package to an older gentleman, receiving a letter in exchange. As the doctor begins opening the package, he restrains her from leaving, forcing her to remain seated. Holmes appears, preventing a hidden switch from triggering, then kisses Irene while deftly stealing the letter from her possession. The doctor unveils the package's contents: a banknote concealing dynamite. Chaos erupts when his pipe accidentally ignites a tapestry, prompting an evacuation. While Irene attempts unsuccessfully to recover the letter before departing, Holmes retrieves the ticking package from the doctor and races to contain it within a sarcophagus, where it detonates.

Outside, Holmes, now disheveled, draws curious looks from well-dressed onlookers. A mysterious bearded man in tweed observes him intently but averts his gaze when noticed. Holmes, his Oriental jacket dust-covered from the explosion, discovers the doctor unconscious against a wall. Upon examination, he finds a small dart in the man's thigh, but when he turns back, the bearded observer has vanished. Holmes carefully preserves the dart in his bag.

The scene shifts to an opulent restaurant with an ornate ceiling. Irene Adler is seated near a curtained table. After her tea is served, the bearded man in tweed signals with a teaspoon against glass, prompting all other patrons and staff to exit. Irene watches anxiously as the establishment empties. The man behind the curtain reveals himself - another bearded individual with weathered features.
942:
In a tense scene, Mycroft's wince preludes a sequence of events at a gaming establishment. While Watson enjoys success at the card tables and Mycroft engages in conversation, Holmes pursues his investigation upstairs, following the trail of a mysterious bearded man he'd spotted earlier carrying a nosegay.

Behind the curtains, Holmes discovers a table adorned with nosegays and encounters a high-cheekboned brunette - Madam Sim - who stands with her back turned. After depositing coins in a shell-shaped bowl, he takes a seat as she lights a match from a candle and produces a deck of tarot cards. Holmes studies the cards intensely, his finger pressed to his forehead, before taking the deck and deliberately placing the Devil card on the table. He then reveals a letter containing a sketch of a goateed man, which visibly startles Sim. Following a meaningful exchange of looks, Sim reaches for her weapon as Holmes rises.

The subsequent confrontation with the Corsac unfolds in Holmes' tactical mind before the actual fight begins. Armed with an umbrella, Holmes executes a precisely planned series of moves: disarming the knife-wielding Corsac, delivering calculated karate chops to his face, and using the umbrella with brutal efficiency. The imagined sequence culminates in Holmes throwing his opponent over his shoulder.

In reality, Holmes pulls the Corsac down from the rafters and disarms him, leading to Sim's apparent fatal intervention with a thrown knife. However, the Corsac proves resilient, recovering and shedding his knife-embedded coat before pursuing them with another blade. He demonstrates remarkable agility, running along a balcony edge and performing an acrobatic somersault to intercept his targets.

The chase intensifies as Holmes engages in hand-to-hand combat, while Watson remains absorbed in his successful gambling below. Sim joins the fray, striking the Corsac with a bottle as Holmes grapples with him on a sofa. During the struggle, the Corsac's blade catches Holmes' cheek, causing him to recoil. The confrontation reaches its climax as Holmes tackles the fleeing Corsac, who manages to seize Sim by her hair in a final aggressive move.
949:
In the aftermath of a crash, the boys regain their footing as Joe attempts to access the bus's back door. Inside, they discover an unconscious technical sergeant while Nelec recovers and attempts radio contact, the alien violently rocking the vehicle. Joe's efforts to open the locked holding cell are interrupted when Nelec approaches, just as a massive tentacle reaches in, crushing the driver. Desperately, Joe pounds on a cracked window overhead while Nelec arms himself with an assault rifle.

Breaking through the window with his elbow, Joe climbs onto the bus's side, helping Martin, Charles, and Carrie escape through the opening. At the front, a giant spider-like alien attempts to reach Nelec, who responds with sustained assault rifle fire as the creature forces its way inside. The boys scramble down and take cover off-road, watching as Nelec's ammunition runs out before the alien lunges with needle-sharp teeth. From their hiding spot in a ditch, they witness the creature bound off the bus and vanish into the woods.

Meanwhile, Air Force soldiers apprehend Louis at the evacuation center. Joe recovers his locket from Overmyer's body just as a car arrives. Spotting a red bus, Joe drives Donnie's car toward town while Donnie sleeps. Suddenly, a tank opens fire, forcing Joe to swerve evasively as more tanks approach. The boys abandon the car and flee, racing through a back garden, pushing past a washing line, and vaulting over fences to reach the street.

Chaos erupts as they witness a tank being overturned, while soldiers scatter from their malfunctioning equipment spraying ammunition wildly. The boys escape through a playground, pursued by an out-of-control tank, and seek shelter in a hillside house. After rushing upstairs, Joe peers out a window before a shell strike throws them to the floor. As they recover, Charles prepares to treat Martin's explosion-induced broken leg.

Joe and Cary sprint to the cemetery building where Joe had noticed disturbed earth. Finding all doors locked, they force their way inside, discovering a tunnel burrowing into the earth. Cary opens his bag, revealing an array of fireworks. Joe ignites a sparkler and tosses it into the dark tunnel's depths.
95:
Offering his box of chocolates to the nurse beside him, Forrest receives only an apprehensive head shake in response. As he samples a chocolate himself, his gaze drifts to her shoes, then to his own, triggering a distant memory. He squeezes his eyes shut, and suddenly we're transported to his childhood.

Young Forrest sits in a doctor's office, being fitted with orthopedic shoes and metal leg braces. The doctor helps him stand, and he takes his first awkward steps, moving stiffly as his mother, Mrs. Gump, watches him clank around the room. When they venture outside, a loud thud signals Forrest's fall.

As mother and son walk across the street, a black and white photograph of General Nathan Bedford Forrest comes into view. The image transforms, showing the General donning a Ku Klux Klan hood and riding off on horseback, leading a large group of similarly dressed Klan members.

Back in young Forrest's world, his brace suddenly catches in a gutter grate while crossing the street. As Mrs. Gump stoops to free him, two elderly men observe from their perch outside a barber shop. Once freed, mother and son continue their journey, Mrs. Gump clutching Forrest's hand tightly as they walk past the onlookers, down a dirt road lined with mailboxes, and up the driveway to their boarding house.

At the principal's office, Forrest waits outside while his mother meets with the administrator. Later, at home, Forrest sits on a porch swing, hearing strange grunting noises emanating from inside. The principal emerges, wiping sweat from his face and neck, appearing embarrassed when Forrest mimics his grunting sound.

The scene shifts to Forrest lying in bed, while outside, various visitors come and go: a cab driver unloading luggage for two women, a milkman departing the porch, and a man with a cane moving through the hall.
950:
A Jeep travels along a dark, quiet road with Jack at the wheel and Louis in the passenger seat. Louis casts troubled glances at Jack, who maintains an unwavering focus on the road ahead despite clearly wrestling with intense emotions. Their eyes briefly meet when Louis looks over again.

At a cemetery, Joe and Cary descend about 30 feet via rope into an alien-constructed tunnel. Standing at the pit's edge, they observe the depth before climbing down. Armed with sparklers for light, they navigate the gloomy passageway, hurrying through the large bore tunnel toward a faint flickering light ahead.

Rounding a corner, they discover a massive chamber carved into the subterranean rock. As they cautiously approach, they find it filled with machinery and evidence of large-scale industrial construction. Their horror mounts as they encounter the sheriff suspended upside down from the tunnel's roof, either dead or unconscious. Joe silences Cary's impending scream with his hand as they observe more motionless bodies hanging from the ceiling.

The alien appears in the chamber, manipulating something behind machinery while holding what appears to be a severed human leg before scuttling away. Among the suspended victims, Joe spots Alice. He rushes back through the tunnel with a sparkler, reaching a fork while Cary empties his bag of pyrotechnics. As Cary selects particularly loud fireworks, he observes the alien working on its mysterious construction, with Alice still suspended motionless above.

The tunnel fork leads Joe near Alice's position, where he watches the alien continue its work. Cary struggles with his lighter as the creature, unaware of their presence, removes Alice from her suspended position. Joe observes with increasing anxiety while Cary finally ignites his Zippo, lighting a firecracker near a cache of other fireworks before fleeing down the tunnel.

The alien, drawn by the noise, abandons Alice to investigate. Joe seizes the opportunity, rushing to the unconscious Alice on the chamber floor. Finding her unresponsive, he hesitates before delivering a hard slap. She awakens, staring at him momentarily before embracing him tightly.
951:
Joe appears startled yet intrigued as Tina sits up nearby. Together, they carefully help lower the sheriff. In the darkness of a tunnel, a terrifying chase unfolds as an alien pursues Cary, before suddenly halting its pursuit. Once the sheriff regains his footing, he leads Joe, Alice, and Tina through a labyrinth of alien equipment, illuminating their path with his flashlight.

As Cary rounds a corner, the alien strikes, seizing the sheriff. The group flees in terror, but Tina, trailing behind, is violently grabbed and dragged into the darkness. The creature continues its pursuit of the remaining friends, who eventually find themselves trapped at a dead end.

Emerging from the shadows, the massive alien approaches as Alice and Cary shrink back in fear. Joe, however, stands resolute. The creature rises to its impressive 25-foot height while Joe, demonstrating remarkable courage, steps forward. The alien tilts its head curiously before lifting Joe up to examine him closely. Its skull-like face, complete with enormous mandibles, is terrifying, and its breath rustles Joe's hair. The creature's expression softens as it retracts protective membranes from its eyes. Momentarily distracted by machinery sounds, it glances away before gently returning Joe to the ground and retreating up the tunnel on its multiple legs, leaving Joe breathless and stunned.

The scene shifts to the surface, where Joe, Alice, and Cary join military troops on a town street. A bizarre magnetic phenomenon begins, pulling metallic objects toward the water tower - everything from bins and oil barrels to table lamps and bicycles stick to the structure's surface. A shop window shatters as television sets are pulled through the air. One soldier, desperately clinging to his rifle, is lifted twenty feet before releasing his grip. Even a car rises from a used car lot.

The situation intensifies when a military container truck bursts open, releasing a flood of white cubes. Joe, Alice, and Cary dive for cover as the cubes soar overhead. In a spectacular display, the cubes merge with the cars and other debris, constructing an enormous structure atop the water tower.
952:
As metallic debris streams upward, assembling itself atop the water tower, Joe, Alice, and Cary watch in amazement. Alice's face lights up as the mysterious structure takes form. A Jeep arrives carrying Joe's father Jack and Louis, Alice's dad. After spotting his son, Jack approaches while Joe nudges Alice to notice their fathers' arrival.

The reunions are emotional - Jack embraces Joe tightly, their faces showing both relief and complex emotions as they hold each other close. Nearby, Alice and her father share their own meaningful moment, first studying each other before coming together in an embrace.

Over his father's shoulder, Joe witnesses the alien ascending the water tower. The creature enters its newly-formed spaceship - a structure resembling a palm tree canopy - and the door seals behind it. As the craft powers up, its rotating arms illuminate with brilliant lights. Joe breaks away from his father just in time to catch his mother's locket, which is being pulled by an invisible force. The locket opens mid-air, revealing a photo of Joe's mother holding him as an infant. After a moment's hesitation, Joe releases the chain, watching as the locket floats up and attaches to the tower.

Suddenly, the water tower explodes, drenching the street below. The spacecraft rises as the tower collapses, crushing military vehicles and sending soldiers scrambling. Charles and Martin, limping through town, observe the ascent, while Donny remains peacefully asleep in his car as the craft's lights reflect off his windshield.

Joe and Alice join hands, their faces breaking into smiles as they watch the spacecraft climb higher with Jack, Louis, and the others. The vessel shrinks to a mere point of light before vanishing completely into the night sky.

The scene shifts to a crime scene at Romero Chemicals, where Martin plays a detective investigating near a chalk outline, consulting with a witness. The sequence concludes with Preston, acting as President, making a phone call.
954:
A violent crash rocks the Earth nearby, followed by fierce, bestial sounds emanating from the damaged train carriage. Amidst the wreckage, a Cinay camera runs out of film on what remains of the platform, while a remarkably intact yellow Coupe sits surrounded by destruction.

Joe navigates through the debris, searching for his companions. Climbing onto twisted railway tracks, he spots Preston, who gives him a reassuring thumbs up. A concerning blood stain catches Joe's attention, and as he approaches it cautiously, the others gather around. Alice appears behind the group, prompting a smile from Joe before he turns back to examine the bloodied wreckage.

After retrieving his makeup box, Joe notices Alice spotting a locket in his possession, which he hastily conceals in his pocket. He then pockets one of the curious white cubes scattered among the debris before joining the others atop a wrecked carriage, where they survey the extensive destruction below. Joe indicates the mangled remains of a white pickup truck.

Descending from their perch, they discover an unconscious black man at the truck's wheel. Alice approaches him cautiously while the boys observe. When she touches his arm, it falls limply, and a document slips from his grasp. The group crowds around as Alice retrieves and unfolds what appears to be a map.

Suddenly, Dr. Woodward snatches the map and sits up stiffly, surveying the children before drawing a revolver. With approaching figures in the distance, the kids scatter in panic. Alice rushes to the Coupe while the boys gather their equipment, including the camera. They barely manage to escape as numerous armed military personnel with flashlights converge on the scene. The soldiers watch their departure, one of them thoughtfully examining an abandoned Super 8 film box.

Back in town, the boys exit the vehicle, and Alice returns Joe's white cube to him. They share a meaningful look, their faces still marked with soot from the explosions, before Alice drives away as the boys watch her departure.

Later, Joe contemplates the textured white cube while soaking in the bath, gazing pensively into space. The town of Lillian's lights sparkle in the night sky from a distant hillside view.

The following morning, Joe wakes up in his bed. He later puts out dog food before running to the Kaznyk's house with a script in hand, where he joins Charles watching television.
956:
In a terrifying encounter, a man frantically rushes back into a shop, pursued by an unseen force that violently shatters the windows, throws him down, and drags him away into the darkness.

The following day, we find Joe applying zombie makeup to Alice. She gives him an inquisitive look and thoughtfully nods as the room's lighting begins to flicker. Getting into character, Alice shambles forward with the vacant stare of the undead, her arms moving in unnatural jerks. The playful scene culminates with her mock-attacking Joe's neck, after which they share an amused glance before she departs. Unknown to them, Charles observes their interaction from afar.

At a devastated gas station, Jack and the manager Eddie survey the damage. The sheriff's vehicle has vanished, leaving only broken light fragments. Nearby, a used car lot's vehicles have been mysteriously stripped of their engines. Jack's suspicion grows as he watches military trucks pass, noticing airmen operating radio detection equipment in one vehicle.

As evening approaches, Joe searches for his missing dog, cycling near a pylon in an open field before dismounting to investigate. Later in town, while posting a lost dog flyer, he makes a disturbing discovery - the community bulletin board is completely covered with similar missing dog notices.

Joe arrives home to find Jack conferring with fellow deputies Tally, Mina, Rosko, Ross, and Jay at the dinner table. A dropped torch breaks the tension as the lights begin to flicker, prompting Jack to radio for assistance.

In the darkness, telecom engineer Rooney works on power lines from his truck's cherry picker near a junkyard. Strange noises draw his attention before scrap metal begins flying through the air, culminating in a cooker crashing onto the road. As Rooney elevates his cherry picker for a better view, the mysterious activity ceases. The surrounding lights start flickering ominously, and his equipment fails. Suddenly, something erupts from the trees, attacking him and smashing his truck's windshield.

The scene shifts to Jack addressing concerned townspeople, concluding with him glaring as Louis is escorted away by a deputy.
961:
Against the cosmic backdrop of a star-filled sky, sunlight begins to peek over Earth's curved horizon, casting golden rays across the continents. A luminous word materializes in orbit, followed by letters cascading into boxes to form a logo.

The scene shifts to a dimly lit stone corridor, where a solitary figure stands beneath towering vaulted ceilings, his form outlined against an ornate iron and glass door. He's wearing an elegant overcoat, absently fidgeting with a wrapped cough drop.

David's campaign unfolds in a series of vignettes: supporters wave placards, he connects with suburban voters, navigates choppy waters on a Coast Guard vessel, and engages with a farmer in rural areas. He appears alongside Mayor Bloomberg at City Hall, moves through a bar setting, and addresses massive crowds. His political gravitas is evident as he converses with prominent figures like Madeleine Albright, Wesley Clark, and Jesse Jackson.

Outside Fordham University's Keating Hall, a young man in a newsboy cap, V-neck, and tie watches intently, applauding with serious interest. As David beams at his supporters, behind the scenes an aide rushes to his campaign chairman, Charlie, who abruptly closes a newspaper. Meanwhile, the young man in the newsboy cap reads a thin hardcover book before answering his phone, his trim mustache twitching as he speaks.

The narrative moves to a conservative hotel suite where David arrives with his bags. He retrieves a folder but leaves it untouched, preferring to gaze despondently at the cityscape before turning to television for distraction. On a downtown rooftop, four distinguished men in fedoras and overcoats approach the guardrail - among them, the mustached young man from earlier. The eldest speaks, briefly glancing at his mustached companion.

Back in the suite, Charlie joins David, manipulating the TV remote before tossing him a red-and-blue striped tie. Their subsequent dejected postures suggest bad news, confirmed when a woman delivers a note that sends David striding away, Charlie following. David exits the Elegant Function Room as news broadcasts play on screens.

The final sequence finds David alone in a grand hallway, hands in pockets and head lowered, before entering an opulent men's room. He reviews note cards, moving across the marble floor over time, then washes up and adjusts his New York-shaped lapel pin. As he glances toward the row of stall doors, one opens to reveal a beautiful woman in a silk spaghetti-strap dress with black lace detailing, emerging with shy hesitation.
963:
In a tense moment at the hospital, he holds her briefly before pulling away with a forced smile. Elise responds with tenderness, but concern fills her eyes as she watches him turn and leave. His discouraged departure from the emergency room draws a pained expression across her face. David's solitary figure trudges down the corridor, his suffering evident in his distant stare, becoming a lonely silhouette against the sterile hospital walls.

The scene shifts to a marble-lined hallway where Richardson joins Harry at a window overlooking New York City. Harry maintains his fixed gaze while, elsewhere in the hospital, Elise sits alone in the waiting room, fighting back tears before being wheeled out by a friend. Back at the window, Harry gives Richardson a skeptical look before the latter dons his fedora, offers a companionable pat, and leaves Harry alone in the mid-century high-rise.

Eleven months pass, and the story finds David walking through a sun-drenched farm pasture. He addresses a crowd near a barn and silos while Charlie and an aide monitor a news report from inside a campaign bus. As Charlie steps outside, the campaign chairman perches on a picnic table, studying a newspaper with growing concern. After the crowd disperses, David approaches, and Charlie presents him with the arts section featuring two photos of Elise - one of her dancing, another with a bow. David examines the images with furrowed brows before departing, leaving Charlie watching him with pressed lips.

The narrative follows David to a waterfront warehouse where he sits wearing a troubled expression. Under darkening skies, he traverses an empty shipping dock, carelessly splashing through a reflective puddle before pausing at the edge to contemplate the setting sun. Meanwhile, Elise sits in her apartment, examining a document with visible distress.

Events culminate as David enters a shabby bar, with Harry mysteriously appearing from an adjacent doorway. Inside, David sits dejectedly while the bartender passes him a note. Later, through pouring rain, David runs along the dock toward a warehouse, shielding himself with his jacket. As evening falls, he waits against a wall until Harry arrives, protected by an umbrella, wearing his signature fedora and trench coat. Harry approaches David, drops his gaze, and draws a heavy breath before gravely shaking his head and settling onto nearby shipping pallets.
966:
In a decisive moment, David protects Elise by halting traffic with an outstretched hand and guiding her across the street. They wade through water to reach a grassy isle, where Elise gazes up to find the Statue of Liberty looming overhead. Upon discovering a pair of doors, David turns to face Elise, whose eyes well with tears. She drops her gaze, considers his sincere expression, and as a tear traces down her face, she responds with a brave nod before taking his hand.

Together they approach double doors, and David grasps the right-hand knob. As they turn the handles in unison, they reveal a lengthy corridor with gleaming marble flooring. The doors seal shut behind them as they enter, while outside, Thompson and his aide watch in astonishment. Their plan books reveal David and Elise's converging paths, marked by flashing red dots. At the bureau, Harry observes the same pattern and steps away with gravity.

The couple bursts into the bureau reading room, with David forcefully clearing their path by pushing aside staffers. They race along the room's perimeter walkway and through another door, just as Thompson and his team make their entrance, commanding attention as they march down the central aisle. David and Elise ascend a magnificent spiral staircase while Thompson's group pursues them along the same route. Looking up, David sees the seemingly endless spiral of stairs above them.

In a white marble hallway, a staffer presents a manila envelope to Harry, who grimly accepts it before departing. A black-clad intervention team moves through an arched colonnade as Thompson's group continues their pursuit, with Thompson pausing to slide open a bronze-barred door at a landing.

David and Elise navigate through a series of corridors and offices, occasionally glancing back for pursuers. They pass through a green-carpeted office where a scholarly receptionist looks up, continuing through identical offices where David maintains his composure enough to wave cordially at a staffer. Meanwhile, the intervention team enters a records archive filled with white-spined volumes on countless shelves.

The chase intensifies as David and Elise enter another records room, only to find intervention teams approaching from both sides. Desperately maneuvering through the labyrinthine connected records rooms, they finally discover a dark green door set in green marble, which David pulls open with urgency.
969:
After slamming down the phone receiver, David cautiously approaches the hallway door. When the opposite door swings open, helmeted assailants seize him, forcefully pinning him to the ground despite his resistance. A mysterious man with a mustache crouches down and presses a cloth against David's face, causing his consciousness to fade.

David regains partial awareness to find himself being carried by the helmeted figures beneath bright lights and a towering ceiling. He later discovers himself restrained in a stark warehouse, his wrists bound, while a white-haired superior makes a phone call. After hanging up, the man studies David, who's confined to a chair, consulting a book before exchanging glances with a balding associate. The white-haired man approaches David with a smile.

In a desperate attempt, David breaks free from his restraints and bolts, but Richardson telekinetically lifts a floor tile, causing him to stumble. Two men in body suits quickly apprehend him and force him back to his seat while the mustached stranger observes. David, clearly distressed, covers his face and rocks back and forth.

As four men exit an SUV, Richardson confronts David, whose jaw drops in disbelief. After Richardson stands and his chair is removed, he stares down at a nodding David. Two men restrain David while Richardson's boyish partner retrieves a business card from David's wallet. Richardson sets it ablaze, watching it burn completely before the wallet is returned to David. With a pointed finger, Richardson signals for two men to escort David to a door, where they throw him headfirst through the opening.

David lands in Charlie's office, and as one door closes, Charlie enters through another. Confused, David finds only a small conference room behind the other door. He watches Charlie skeptically as he hangs up his phone and adjusts a crooked picture. David enters the conference room, followed by Charlie, and encounters Susan, the receptionist, at the bottom of some stairs, responding to her smile with unease.

Later in the conference room, David sits at the long table, bewildered, while Charlie paces during a woman's presentation to colleagues. Charlie offers a slight shrug and smiles, meeting David's confused stare. David attempts to focus, shrugging helplessly. The scene concludes with David observing a secretary on the phone while passing her cubicle with a friend, before Charlie leads him inside and leans against his desk with folded arms.
971:
Pursuing Elise down the street, David catches up just as she makes another turn. She stops, grins playfully, and squirms while catching her breath before eyeing him carefully.

Meanwhile, a boyish officer hurries down a corridor and enters the office of Mr. Richardson, a veteran officer seated at his desk. After showing a map book, Richardson grabs his brown fedora. In the hallway, they pass Harry, who respectfully tips his hat, before the boyish officer, now wearing his own hat, follows Richardson through a doorway.

They enter a café and spot David and Elise. As the host seats them, the boyish officer consults his map book, which displays pulsing red dots. Outside, David glances around nervously while Elise secretly smiles at him from their outdoor table. The officers share a nearby table as a server fills David's water glass.

Richardson and his aide take up a strategic position overlooking the dining area. The aide's map book shows an intensifying red inflection point. Charlie arrives, followed by a third officer. As Charlie settles the check, Elise grins at David. Under Richardson's watchful eye, the couple lean in for a kiss, but Richardson's well-timed text to Charlie interrupts the moment. David recovers smoothly, giving Elise a lingering kiss on the cheek instead. Richardson bows his head in relief as Elise responds with a radiant smile.

Later, near the Brooklyn Bridge, David exits a Town Car to numerous handshakes before taking the podium at a campaign event overlooking the East River, addressing hundreds. Richardson's aide receives a text about moving the rehearsal to Cedar Lake as David gazes toward Pier 17. In her eclectic apartment, Elise checks her phone, receiving the same message about the relocated rehearsal.

As David's senate race gathering concludes, he spots Richardson in a window, but the Adjustment officers quickly duck out of sight. Frowning at both Pier 17 and the empty window, David boards a water taxi across the river. Upon reaching the pier, he hurriedly climbs the stairs and follows a covered walkway alongside a renovated warehouse, only to find a studio door chain-locked. His attempted phone call fails due to lost signal, prompting him to leave the pier with determination.

Richardson and his aide monitor his movements through their map book as David rounds a corner, coming face-to-face with the two officers.
972:
David enters the scene, accompanied by others. He fixes his gaze on a boyish officer, who responds by closing his map book. Richardson, under David's intense stare, slightly furrows his brow. David then crosses to a nearby bistro.

While the boyish aide consults his book again, the Adjustment officers observe David's quick exit. At the curb, David attempts to hail several cabs - first one that switches to "off duty," then a mini-van taxi that ignores him, and finally another cab that passes by despite his animated waving in the opposite lane. Richardson and his aide maintain a casual presence, exchanging meaningful glances as David jogs away.

Desperately, David sprints in his dress shoes after another cab. Just as the driver acknowledges him, a sedan violently collides with the taxi's passenger side. David rushes to the accident scene, noting the bloody-faced cabbie being attended to by the sedan's driver. After checking on both drivers and making a phone call, David approaches another police officer, who, after a glance toward Richardson, withdraws from the scene. Finding no one else to help, David leaves behind the emergency vehicles and begins running again after checking his watch.

Finally securing a taxi, David's escape is complicated by a red light and stopping traffic. A couple in the crosswalk scrambles to safety as David spots Richardson and his aide emerging nearby. The taxi successfully evades the Bureau servants, who begin an unusual pursuit through various portals - from a pub's side door to a street, through what appears to be a closet to confused hostess, and even through a residential door leading impossibly to Central Park.

The chase intensifies as the officers race through a townhouse and an art gallery, disrupting a bystander, while David's cab navigates the streets. As David exits his taxi and enters a building, Richardson loses his hat. Inside, David opens a door to find Elise performing a dance move. Richardson, breathless, makes eye contact with David before receiving a cellphone from his aide and departing.

David becomes transfixed by Elise's performance as she dances with a male partner, who supports her waist. She executes a series of graceful movements - balancing on one foot, bending forward with her other foot raised behind her, and rolling smoothly across her partner's back as he lunges deeply. David enters the studio while Richardson exits to a marble-faced building, disappearing through brass doors into a towering midcentury high-rise with countless stories stretching skyward.
985:
In a fateful encounter, Thomas finds himself confronted by a maid before forcefully pushing past her to reach a cot containing an infant. Upon discovering the child, he recoils in horror, gagging at the sight, while nearby a priest administers last rites to the dying mother. Without hesitation, Thomas snatches the baby and flees, rushing downstairs and out of the house with the blanket-wrapped infant in his arms.

He tears through the streets, stumbling past festive revelers, including one clutching a bottle of alcohol, until he reaches the edge of a dark river. His moment of respite is interrupted by a lantern-wielding policeman emerging from a warehouse. Thomas glances leftward before sprinting along the river path, the policeman's whistle piercing the night air as he gives chase.

Weaving through the gloom behind warehouses, Thomas emerges onto a dimly lit road, navigating between slow-moving vehicles before seeking refuge in the shadows. As the pursuing officer scans the area, Thomas slips through a concrete wall's gateway, concealing himself and the baby while the policeman rushes past unknowingly.

Breathing a sigh of relief, Thomas steps into a pool of light cast from a nearby window. Still trembling, he rounds a corner and approaches a clapboard building's back steps. There, he gently places the baby on the fourth step, tucking money into its blanket before hiding as a young black couple emerges onto their back porch. He observes as the bespectacled man, Tizzy, dressed impressively in a fine suit and bowler hat, stands beside his wife, who dabs herself with a cloth while suppressing a smile, the abandoned infant just feet away.

Upon discovering the baby, Queenie unwraps the blanket, revealing an infant with an unusually aged, wrinkled face. She and Tizzy gasp in astonishment before she carefully lifts the child and carries it into their house, heading to her basement room. After closing her door on a pearl-necklaced elderly resident, Queenie carefully removes the blanket from the baby's face and temporarily places it in a dresser drawer before addressing Mrs. Hollister at the door.

In the retirement home, amid aged residents and laughing white-haired women, Dr. Rose examines the peculiar infant after Queenie's discreet consultation. Together they contemplate the naked baby before Queenie carries it to the retirement home lounge, adjusting its blanket and gazing down at the extraordinary child with wonder.

At the helm of a ship, Benjamin turns the wheel before Mike, cigar clenched between his teeth, takes control with a grin and steers hard to port. Later, the two men find themselves in a dimly lit bar where Mike, after taking a drink, removes his shirt to reveal an impressive collection of tattoos. He playfully strikes boxing poses and kisses his decorated bicep, flashing Benjamin another grin.

The scene shifts to a staircase where prostitutes gather, and a striking woman steps forward. Benjamin and the woman ascend the stairs together. After their encounter, marked by moving bedsheets and the woman's weary emergence, Benjamin hurriedly exits, passing scantily clad women as he escapes through the back door into a crowded alley. In a twist of fate, his father Thomas, leaving a different prostitute nearby, spots him.

Thomas's motorcar follows Benjamin along a rain-slicked street. After some contemplation, Thomas, sporting a neat mustache, offers his son a ride. Inside a bar, father and son are served whiskeys by a waiter. They share a drink, with Thomas smiling wryly as Benjamin struggles with the strong liquor. As the evening progresses and bar staff begin cleaning up, they continue drinking, with Thomas now coughing on his own whiskey while Benjamin confidently downs his.

The night ends with Thomas dropping Benjamin at his front gate. Benjamin, wearing a fedora, stumbles towards his door and through the dark hallway, where Queenie waits with crossed arms. His inebriation culminates in violent illness.

Years later, when Daisy is around nine, Benjamin sneaks into her room early one morning to wake her. They venture out together in the dawn light, Benjamin running ahead until they reach Captain Mike's tugboat. They find the tattooed sailor in a deep, drunken sleep. Upon waking, Mike eyes Daisy, rubs his decorated chest, and puts a cigar in his mouth.

The tugboat navigates through dense fog along the river, with Benjamin and Daisy standing at the prow. Benjamin, wearing a woolen hat, glances back at Daisy while Mike drinks coffee from an enamel cup in the wheelhouse. As an ocean liner passes, Daisy and Benjamin climb to the wheelhouse, where she waves at the larger vessel, sharing a meaningful smile with Benjamin.

The narrative shifts to a hospital scene where Caroline turns to Daisy, who gazes out a window as lightning flashes. Caroline begins reading from a diary. In a final scene, Benjamin examines himself in a mirror before turning his attention to the motionless Mrs. Maple, who sits lifeless in her chair, head back, with vacant eyes and slightly parted lips.

In the dark night, Myrtle's lifeless body lies on the road, a deep gash marring her chest, while Daisy and Gatsby flee the scene in their car. Another motorist stops to witness the grim tableau, as the faded billboard of Dr. T.J. Eckleburg's enormous eyes gazes emptily over the tragedy.

Tom arrives with Nick and Jordan, just as police begin securing the area near Wilson's garage where onlookers have congregated. The sight of a devastated Wilson draws Tom's concerned attention. As officers manage the growing crowd, they cover Myrtle's body, now placed on a table. Unable to resist, Tom approaches and pulls back the sheet, revealing her blood-stained remains. He gasps in shock while Nick respectfully removes his cap, both men standing in stunned silence.

Tom takes charge of the situation, restraining a distraught Wilson despite a skeptical older officer's doubts. After the policeman departs, Tom tends to the shell-shocked Wilson, offering him a drink. Wilson, tears streaming down his face, accepts the glass, pressing it against his skin in a daze. In an uncharacteristically tender moment, Tom comforts Wilson, awkwardly rubbing his back as Wilson leans against him for support. Meanwhile, Nick solemnly recovers Myrtle's body with the sheet.

The night progresses as Tom and Jordan drive away in their gleaming blue coupe, arriving at the Buchanan mansion where servants await. A tense sequence of interactions unfolds on the porch: Tom studies Nick before dismissively entering the house, Jordan storms inside after receiving Nick's pointed glare, and Nick, deeply troubled, takes his leave.

In the shadows, Nick discovers Gatsby concealing himself behind shrubbery. When the butler Henri briefly illuminates the scene by switching on lights and checking the porch, Gatsby's face is momentarily exposed before darkness returns. As Gatsby anxiously watches the upstairs windows, he reveals the truth through a haunting flashback: Daisy had been driving when Myrtle crashed into their windscreen and was thrown through the air.

The night concludes with Nick secretly observing through the terrace as Tom consoles a shell-shocked Daisy at their dining table, while Gatsby remains outside, devastated and alone, bearing the weight of a tragedy he didn't directly cause.
998:
In his room, Nick begins writing as he stares at a silver pencil resting on a blank page beside an open book left by the doctor who had just visited him. The scene shifts to a gritty industrial landscape where men toil on hills of coal waste, swinging pickaxes against the dark mounds.

Nick and Tom find themselves aboard a crowded train. When it stops, they hastily disembark and make their way to a garage where Tom introduces Nick to Myrtle. After exchanging knowing looks, Tom discretely passes her money while Nick stands by uncomfortably.

The scene transitions to Myrtle's apartment in town, its garishly decorated living room dominated by red walls, ornate furnishings, and excessive floral prints. Nick sits uneasily on the couch, watching Myrtle's small dog feast on leftover food. Growing increasingly uncomfortable with the sounds of Tom and Myrtle's activities upstairs, Nick attempts to leave, donning his straw boater. At the door, he encounters a seductive young woman wearing heavy eye makeup and a green dress, just as Myrtle reappears. Nick's resolve weakens with a smile.

The party intensifies as Tom lifts Nick up and Catherine wraps herself around him in a chair. She passes him a pill through a kiss, while Tom embraces Myrtle nearby. Catherine helps Nick drink as the revelry escalates - Tom and Myrtle dance together while Nick pairs with Catherine, Chester capturing the moments with his camera. Tom opens champagne and playfully hits Nick with a pillow, sending feathers flying everywhere.

Against the backdrop of a trumpet player on the fire escape, the party grows wilder. Tom spins Nick around as Catherine kisses him and removes his shirt. The women strip to their underwear as everyone dances. Nick, clearly intoxicated, watches with Catherine beside him as Myrtle provocatively dances, pulling at her red dress.

In his drugged state, Nick experiences double vision - seeing another version of himself popping champagne and drinking exuberantly, while the real Nick receives champagne from Tom's ceramic goblet. He watches his alternate self rolling on a bed with Catherine while he sways dizzily. At the window, he observes a young black woman gazing out from her apartment, and sees yet another version of himself on the street below.

The party takes a dark turn when Nick discovers Chester asleep and wipes cream from his face. Myrtle and Tom burst in, and Tom violently strikes her across the face. Nick escapes to the fire escape as the city seems to fade away before him.
